revision.text:
{{about|samples of Hip Hop Movement as the new Civil Rights Movement & Music Genre|the music genre|Hip hop music|other uses|Hip hop}} [[File:Hip Hop Movementpng.png|thumb|Hip Hop Movement Logo]] [[File:640 × 960 Hon. Ronald Savage at a Press Release.jpg|thumb|Ronald "Bee-Stinger" Savage carved the term Six elements of the Hip Hop Movement]]
'''The [[Hip Hop]] Movement''' offers a critical theory and history of hip hop culture as stated by [[Reiland Rabaka]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.colorado.edu/ethnicstudies/people/rabaka/|title=People :: Reiland Rabaka :: University of Colorado Ethnic Studies|website=www.colorado.edu|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref> in his book ''The Hip Hop Movement: From R&B and the Civil Rights Movement to Rap and the Hip Hop Generation''. The movement connects [[R & B|R&B]], the [[Civil Rights Movement]], and hip hop culture.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://artsedge.kennedy-center.org/students/features/series/hip-hop|title=ARTSEDGE: Hip-Hop: A Culture of Vision and Voice|first=The Kennedy Center|last=ArtsEdge|website=artsedge.kennedy-center.org}}</ref> <ref>http://www.hiphopmovement.org/about-us.html</ref>The six elements Of the Hip Hop Movement are: Consciousness Awareness, Civil Rights Awareness, Activism Awareness, Justice, Political Awareness, Community Awareness in music. In 1990 while working with the rap/pop group [[Snap!]] [[Ronald Savage|Ronald "Bee-Stinger" Savage]] while in the [[State of New York]] carved the term Six elements of the Hip Hop Movement.The Hip Hop Movement is not only to entertain people but also to enlighten listeners of the struggle, the oppressed, and those who through lyrics to connect with.<ref>https://www.birthofhiphop.com/1184-2/</ref><ref>https://www.amazon.com/Tourette-Syndrome-Discriminated-Harassed-Supervisor/dp/1517027837</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uupetaluma.org/services/getting-trouble-helping-troubled-kids/|title=From Getting in Trouble to Helping Troubled Kids - uupetaluma|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://enspireusall.com/2017/05/17/hip-hop-pioneers-ronald-savage-and-busy-bee-acquire-use-of-the-trademark-for-the-hip-hop-movement/#.WvTQLYgvzmZ|title=HIP HOP PIONEERS RONALD SAVAGE AND BUSY BEE ACQUIRE USE OF THE TRADEMARK FOR THE HIP HOP MOVEMENT!|website=enspireusall.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kriphopnation.com/the-son-of-hip-hop-ronald-savage-speaks-about-his-disability-discrimination/|title=The Son Of Hip-Hop, Ronald Savage, Speaks About His Disability, Discrimination &…|date=February 6, 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.birthofhiphop.com/1184-2/|title=Jay-Z with Dean Baquet of The New York Times here: - BOHH|date=December 5, 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopmovement.hiphop/|title=Home Page 5|website=Hip Hop Movement}}</ref>
The four elements of hip hop culture are graffiti, rapping, DJing, and break-dancing. Rabaka argues that the hip hop movement is just as deserving of critical scholarly inquiry as other black popular music, such as R & B. Hip hop has been documented to 1973 by [[Steven Hager]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Hip-Hop-Steven-Hager-ebook/dp/B00Q8PFRIQ/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1479353454&sr=1-3&keywords=+Steven+Hager|title=Hip Hop|first=search|last=results|publisher=|via=Amazon}}</ref> The word "hip hop" first appeared in print on September 21, 1981, in ''[[The Village Voice]]'' in a profile story of [[Africa Bambaataa]] written by Hager, who published the first comprehensive history of hip hop culture with St. Martins' Press. Taymullah Abdur-Rahman in a blog in The Huffington Press compares hip hop to The Civil Rights Movement.<ref name="ack">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/taymullah-abdurrahman/hip-hop-a-child-of-the-civil-rights-movement_b_9039664.html|title=Hip-Hop: A Child Of The Civil Rights Movement|first=Taymullah|last=Abdur-Rahman|date=26 January 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Taymullah Abdur-Rahman]] opined "We couldn't reproduce [[Frederick Douglass]] but we had [[KRS-One]]. We didn’t try to imitate [[MLK]] but we had [[Chuck D]]. We remembered [[Harriet Tubman]] when we looked at [[Lauryn Hill]]. We didn’t need the [[Queen of Sheba]], we had our own Queen...''Latifah"''<ref name=ack /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20130809-the-party-where-hip-hop-was-born|title=40 years on from the party where hip hop was born|first=Rebecca|last=Laurence|publisher=}}</ref> [[Jeff Chang (journalist)|Jeff Chang]] in his book, [[Can't Stop Won't Stop (book)|''Can’t Stop Won’t Stop'']] states, "there was no manifesto. The kids who started it were simply trying to find ways to pass the time, they were trying to have fun. They grew up under the politics of abandonment and because of this, their pastimes contained the seeds for a kind of mass cultural renewal."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diversityarts.stanford.edu/people/jeff-chang|title=Jeff Chang - Institute for Diversity in the Arts|website=diversityarts.stanford.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20130809-the-party-where-hip-hop-was-born|title=40 years on from the party where hip hop was born|first=Rebecca|last=Laurence|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Todd Boyd]] in his book ''[[The New H.N.I.C.: The Death of Civil Rights and the Reign of Hip Hop]],'' says "I would suggest that you might get a better read of what's going on in the world of Black people today by listening to DMX on ''It's Dark and Hell is Hot'' than by listening to repeated broadcasts of Martin Luther King speeches."Hip hop is inherently political, the language is political," Boyd says. "It uses language as a weapon — not a weapon to violate or not a weapon to offend, but a weapon that pushes the envelope that provokes people, makes people think.""<ref name="auto">{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1178621|title=Hip Hop: Today's Civil Rights Movement?|newspaper=NPR.org|language=en|access-date=2017-01-26}}</ref><ref name="auto"/>
Ronald Savage<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/afrika-bambaataa-sex-abuse-accuser-ronald-savage-speaks-article-1.2594599|title=Afrika Bambaataa sex abuse accuser Ronald Savage speaks out|newspaper=NY Daily News|language=en|access-date=2017-01-26}}</ref> is the first known elected official in New York State in printed articles to come out of the Zulu Nation that paved the way for hip hop culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/exclusive-daily-news-inspires-queens-mom-fight-justice-article-1.2624019|title=EXCLUSIVE: Daily News’ front page story inspires Queens mom to fight for justice for victims of child abuse - NY Daily News|first=Michael O’keeffe, Larry|last=McShane|publisher=}}</ref> Savage inspired many people with his fight to help change the laws of the [[statute of limitations]] against child molesters in New York State (Child Victims Act) making another statement of the Hip Hop Movement.
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:American hip hop]] [[Category:Culture of New York City]] [[Category:Performing arts in the United States]] [[Category:20th century in the United States]] [[Category:Anti-racism in the United States]]

revision.comment: /* Development */Removed outdated or irrelevant information and changed some tenses to past tense.
revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = Project: Knoxville | image = Knoxville_poster.jpg | caption = Promotional poster of ''Project: Knoxville'' | developer = [[Press Play (company)|Press Play]] | publisher = [[Microsoft Studios]] | platforms = [[Xbox One]] | released =Cancelled | genre = [[Survival game|Survival]], [[action game|action]] | modes = [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] | director = Mikkel Thorsted }}
'''''Project: Knoxville''''' is a cancelled video game developed by [[Press Play (company)|Press Play]] and published by [[Microsoft Studios]] exclusively for the [[Xbox One]].<ref>{{cite web| title=Exclusive: Press Play discuss Project Knoxville, their ambitious and exclusive Xbox One survival game|publisher=windowscentral.com | url=http://www.windowscentral.com/exclusive-press-play-discuss-project-knoxville-their-ambitious-and-exclusive-xbox-one-survival-game | accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> The game puts emphasis on [[survival game|survival]] and lets players co-operate with each other to achieve success. The game adapts an open development and allows the community to give input regarding the game's development. As Press Play was closed in March 2016, the game was no longer in development.
==Gameplay== ''Project: Knoxville'' is a [[third-person perspective|third-person]] [[multiplayer game|multiplayer]] [[survival game]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-09-09-press-plays-next-game-is-project-knoxville|title=Press Play's next game is Project: Knoxville|first=Wesley|last=Yin-Poole|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=September 9, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref> Throughout the game, players can jump, sprint, and interact with the environments. The game's major objective is to survive and escape from an arena which is filled with different hostile enemies. These arenas are round-based, each one lasting for approximately ten to twenty minutes, and the game does not feature a persistent world.<ref name="Skype">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/you-can-choose-which-game-this-studio-makes-next/1100-6429854/|title=You Can Choose Which Game This Studio Makes Next|first=Chris|last=Pereira|date=August 18, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015|work=[[GameSpot]]}}</ref> Players can interact with characters that are controlled by other players, and can choose whether to trust them or to distrust them. The game supports [[co-operative gameplay]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameplanet.com.au/news/g55ef6bd0d66d3/Press-Plays-next-project-is-the-Hunger-Games-inspired-Project-Knoxville/?referrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com.hk%2F|title=Press Play's next game is the Hunger Games-inspired Project Knoxville|first=Andrew|last=Todd|work=[[Gameplanet (New Zealand)]]|date=September 9, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref> As a result, players have the option to demand attention from other players, as well as requesting weapons, healing and currency from them. Some missions require multiple players to work and ally together, or else they will be unable to complete them. Competitive multiplayer elements are also present in the game, in which players can choose to eliminate or backfire at each other.<ref name="Transparent">{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/09/09/knoxville-the-next-game-from-press-play|title=Knoxville: The Next Game From Press Play|work=[[IGN]]|first=Michael|last=Martin|date=September 8, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2015/08/18/you-can-vote-on-press-plays-next-game.aspx|title=You Can Vote On Press Play's Next Game|first=Hershall|last=Cook|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=August 18, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref><ref name="YTPP">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jm4QNxoszTQ|title=Project: Knoxville Prototype Gameplay|publisher=[[Press Play (company)|Press Play]]|work=[[YouTube]]|date=August 18, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref>
In the arena, the player will be accompanied by seven different players at the beginning of each match.<ref name="Transparent"/> They can pick up weapons that are sparsely scattered across the world to defend themselves and attack enemies<ref name="spawn">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/max-the-curse-of-brotherhood-devs-next-game-is-the/1100-6430403/|title=Max: The Curse of Brotherhood Dev's Next Game is The Hunger Games Meets The Running Man And Left 4 Dead|first=Tamoor|last=Hussain|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=September 9, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref> They are also tasked to collect coins, which can be used to escape a level and upgrade the character the player is using. The number of coins in a level is limited, and some players may not be able to collect the coin needed to escape the level, and will get left behind in the arena.<ref name="YTPP"/> Players who die in the game can also enter an Afterlife mode. They can spawn objects that will influence a round, such as enemies or medkit next to surviving characters.<ref name="YTPP"/><ref name="YTPP"/><ref name="spawn"/>
==Development== The game was currently being developed by [[Press Play (company)|Press Play]], who had previously worked on ''[[Max: The Curse of Brotherhood]]'' and ''[[Kalimba (video game)|Kalimba]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-08-18-microsofts-kalimba-and-max-developer-opens-public-vote-on-next-project|title=You can vote on which game the developer of Max: the Curse of Brotherhood makes next|first=Tom|last=Phillips|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=August 18, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref> On August 18, 2015, Press Play revealed three different projects they may work on, and asked the public to vote and choose the one that they wanted the most.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usgamer.net/articles/microsofts-press-play-open-development-process|title=Microsoft's Press Play Opens Its Development Process to the Players|first=Mike|last=Williams|work=[[USgamer]]|date=August 18, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/08/18/max-the-curse-of-brotherhood-and-kalimba-dev-press-play-letting-fans-pick-studios-next-game|title=Max: The Curse of Brotherhood and Kalimba Dev Press Play Letting Fans Pick Studio's Next Game|first=Evan|last=Campbell|work=[[IGN]]|date=August 18, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref> The three projects were ''Project: Dwarka'', ''Project: Karoo'' and ''Project: Knoxville''. ''Dwarka'' is a [[dungeon crawler]] set in a [[first-person perspective]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vg247.com/2015/08/18/xbox-one-knoxville-dwarka-karoo-vote/|title=Vote on which game Max: The Curse of Brotherhood studio develops next|first= Stephany|last=Nunneley|work=[[VG247]]|date=August 18, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref> It tasks players to play as a dwarf and investigate dungeons, which are procedurally generated. '' Karoo'' is a [[simulation game]], which tasks players to build and customize their own vehicles, and explore a wasteland to gather different resources. The third project is ''Knoxville'', which was ultimately chosen by the community.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vg247.com/2015/09/09/knoxville-chosen-as-press-plays-next-project/|title=Knoxville chosen as Press Play’s next project|first=Brenna|last=Hillier|work=[[VG247]]|date=September 9, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref> All of them feature multiplayer components.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/8/18/9174427/developer-press-play-turns-to-players-to-choose-next-game|title=Developer Press Play asks public to choose next project|first=Colin|last=Campbell|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=August 18, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/xbox-studio-press-play-vote-dwarka-karoo-knoxville/|title=Xbox studio is letting you pick its next game|first=Sam|last=Prell|work=[[GamesRadar]]|date=August 18, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref><ref name="GIB">{{cite web|url = http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2015-09-08-press-play-let-gamers-choose-its-next-project|title = Press Play let gamers choose its next project|last = Weber|first = Rachel|date = September 8, 2015|work = Gameindustry.biz|accessdate = September 9, 2015}}</ref>
According to Press Play, the game was inspired by films like ''[[The Running Man (1987 film)|The Running Man]]'' and ''[[The Hunger Games (film)|The Hunger Games]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/press-play-announces-hunger-games-style-knoxville/|title=Press Play announces Hunger Games-style Knoxville|first=Jordan|last=Erica Webber|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=September 9, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref> Similar to the films, they put emphasis on survival and the relationships between players.<ref name="Transparent"/> The game's development was aimed to be transparent,<ref name="Transparent"/> as they would share new information of the game every other week through [[Twitch.tv|Twitch]].<ref name="Transparent"/> Supporters would also get to join meetings of the development team through [[Skype]].<ref name="Skype"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2015/08/19/press-play-open-development-vote/|title=Microsoft studio wants you to choose and shape its next game|first=Aaron|last=Souppouris |date=August 19, 2015|accessdate=September 9, 2015|work=[[Engadget]]}}</ref>
On 7 March 2016 Microsoft announced that [[Press Play (company)|Press Play]] has closed down, and that the development of ''Project: Knoxville'' had ended. The decision was made as Microsoft wished to "focus its investment and development on the games and franchises that fans find most exciting and want to play".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.develop-online.net/news/lionhead-ceases-fable-legends-development-considering-closure/0217545|title=Lionhead ceases Fable Legends development, considering closure|first=Matthew|last=Jarvis|work=[[Develop (magazine)|Develop]]|date=March 7, 2016|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://microsoftstudios.com/press-play/project/knoxville/ Knoxville at Microsoft]
[[Category:Action video games]] [[Category:Cooperative video games]] [[Category:Microsoft games]] [[Category:Survival video games]] [[Category:Multiplayer video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Denmark]] [[Category:Video games with cel-shaded animation]] [[Category:Cancelled Xbox One games]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox webcomic| <!-- Part of [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Webcomics]] --> | title = Le blog de Frantico | image = | caption = | author = Frantico | url = http://www.zanorg.com/frantico/ | status = | began = January 1, 2005 | ended = | genre = Auto-biographical | ratings = }} '''''Le blog de Frantico''''' is a supposedly autobiographical [[Webcomics in France|Franco-Belgian webcomic]] that ran in 2005. It is drawn by Frantico, thought to be a [[pen name]] of [[Lewis Trondheim]]. In his blog, Frantico describes the miseries of his sex life. ''Le blog de Frantico'' was compiled into a comic book published by [[Albin Michel]] in October 2005, and it was nominated for the 2006 [[Angoulême International Comics Festival Prize for First Comic Book|Prize for First Comic Book]] at the [[Angoulême International Comics Festival]]<ref>[http://www.toutenbd.com/article.php3?id_article=1480 ToutenBD.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006093920/http://www.toutenbd.com/article.php3?id_article=1480 |date=October 6, 2014 }}, Angoulême palmarès</ref>
==Content== In ''Le blog de Frantico'', the anonymous author describes the miseries of his daily life, with a specific focus on his sexual life.<ref name=Telerama />
==Author== It is widely speculated that the author of ''Frantico'' is [[Lewis Trondheim]], and though he initially denied it,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tcj.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=639&Itemid=48 |work=[[The Comics Journal]] |title=Lewis Trondheim |last=Wivel |first=Matthias |date=2007-06-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070610060157/http://www.tcj.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=639&Itemid=48 |archive-date=June 10, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> he later admitted that he indeed created the blog.<ref name=Telerama>{{cite web|url=http://www.telerama.fr/livres/M0608071713430.html|work=[[Telerama.fr]]|title=Le maître du dérisoire|date=2006-08-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930014529/http://www.telerama.fr/livres/M0608071713430.html|archivedate=September 30, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The auto-biographical nature of the Frantico webcomic has been confirmed to be false.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} A first comic book compilation of ''Le blog de Frantico'' was published by [[Albin Michel]] in October 2005<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bedetheque.com/serie-12558-BD-Blog-de-Frantico-(Le).html|work=Bédétheque.com|title=Le blog de Frantico}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.zanorg.com/frantico/ ''Le blog de Frantico''] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060410101201/http://www.frantico.info/ ''Frantico'' web forum]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Blog de Frantico, Le}} [[Category:Webcomics in print]] [[Category:Comics publications]] [[Category:French bloggers]] [[Category:2005 webcomic debuts]] [[Category:French webcomics]] [[Category:Autobiographical webcomics]]
{{FrancoBelgian-comics-stub}} {{webcomic-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = Library Access to Music Project | logo = | logocaption = | screenshot = | caption = | url = {{URL|lamp.mit.edu}} | slogan = | commercial = no | type = | registration = | language = | num_users = | content_license = Server software [[GPLv2]] (or, at your option, any later version); music is not generally licensed for redistribution | programming language = [[Perl]], [[PHP]], [[C++]] | owner = MIT's [[Student Information Processing Board]] and Cable Television groups | author = [[Keith Winstein]], [[Joshua Mandel]], and others | launch_date = {{Start date and age|2003|10|27}} | current_status = | footnotes = }} The '''Library Access to Music Project''' (LAMP) is a free music library for [[MIT]] students started by [[Keith Winstein]] and [[Joshua Mandel]], and funded by the MIT/Microsoft iCampus alliance. Originally launched on October 27, 2003,<ref name="nyt-cable">{{cite news|last=Schwartz|first=John|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/27/business/technology-with-cable-tv-at-mit-who-needs-napster.html|title=With Cable TV at M.I.T., Who Needs Napster?|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=27 October 2003|accessdate=27 July 2013}}</ref> it has been in continuous operation since October 25, 2004.
== Using LAMP == A student wishing to use LAMP goes to the LAMP website, and selects several songs. LAMP assigns to the student a channel on MIT [[cable television|Cable]] (e.g. Channel 63), then begins playing the selected music on that channel for anyone to listen to.<ref name="usatoday2003">{{cite news|last=Graham|first=Jefferson|title=LAMP lights way for those seeking free, legal, Net tunes|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/2003-10-26-mit-music_x.htm|accessdate=27 July 2013|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=26 October 2003}}</ref>
== Legal Significance == One key advantage of LAMP, in addition to its being free for its users, is the fact that any piece of music is in theory available on it because [[copyright]] law is more lax about broadcasting over analog transmissions, such as MIT Cable, than it is about digital transmissions such as those made over computer networks.<ref name="nyt-cable"/> For example, a person wanting to transmit a copy of "... Baby One More Time", written by [[Max Martin]] and performed by [[Britney Spears]], could do it either with an analog transmission or a digital transmission. Using an analog transmission would only require permission from [[Bertelsmann Music Group|BMG]], the publisher, whereas use of a digital transmission would require Spears's permission as well.<ref>{{cite book | last = Kohn | first = Al | title = Kohn on music licensing | publisher = Aspen Publishers | location = Frederick, MD | year = 2010 | isbn = 0735590907 |page=1469|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0vkIhwzTs_UC&pg=PA1469}}</ref>
This aspect of copyright law is problematic for those wishing to transmit songs by artists such as [[The Beatles]]. Their label, [[Apple Corps]], as well as others, typically do not allow digital transmissions of their music, which is why their songs were not available on online music stores such as [[iTunes Store|iTunes]] until late 2010. However, songs by The Beatles are available on LAMP, since LAMP doesn't require Apple Corps's permission.
Initially, MIT purchased audio from [[LoudEye]], Inc., in MP3 form.<ref>{{cite web|title=Loudeye Supports Launch of MIT's Electronic Music Library; Massachusetts Institute of Technology Unveils On-Demand Electronic Music Library Leveraging Loudeye's Digital Media Services.|url=http://lamp.mit.edu/loudeye.txt|publisher=PR Newswire|accessdate=27 July 2013|author=Loudeye Corp.|date=27 October 2003}}</ref> However, on the day of LAMP's initial launch, [[Universal Music Group]] approached Loudeye with concerns that it lacked the necessary licenses to make the MP3s that were sold to MIT.<ref name=st03>{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Kim|title=Loudeye's hard music lesson plants it in center of controversy|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/businesstechnology/2001783243_loudeye05.html|accessdate=27 July 2013|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=5 November 2003}}</ref> Without music, LAMP was forced to go on a hiatus of about one year, until a different method of obtaining music was devised.<ref name=tech-lamp-returns>{{cite news|last=Chang|first=Jeffrey|title=After Legal Issues, LAMP Returns to MIT|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V124/PDF/N48.pdf|accessdate=27 July 2013|newspaper=[[The Tech (newspaper)|The Tech]]|date=26 October 2004|pages=1, 14}}</ref>
LAMP in its current incarnation requires someone to purchase a physical CD and place it in a CD jukebox, where it is then turned into an MP3. However, ripping MP3s of individual songs at will is still legally questionable, so LAMP takes advantage of the "ephemeral recording" provision of copyright law. Under this provision, consumers can create a "transmission program" so long as it is designed to be played back as a whole, in sequence. LAMP currently uses "transmission programs" that are approximately 30 minutes in length.<ref name=tech-lamp-returns/>
==Technical information== LAMP is appropriately built with [[LAMP (software bundle)|LAMP]] technologies. That is to say, it runs on Linux machines, uses an Apache webserver, a MySQL database, and Perl and PHP. Portions of the software are also written in C++.<ref>{{cite web|title=Frequently Asked Questions|url=http://lamp.mit.edu/lamp-qa.html|publisher=LAMP project|accessdate=28 July 2013|date=20 October 2004}}</ref>
== References == <references/>
==External links== *[http://lamp.mit.edu/ LAMP's website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Library Access To Music Project}} [[Category:Music organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Music websites]] [[Category:Music libraries]]

{{no footnotes|date=May 2017}} The following is a list of home video releases ([[DVD]] and [[VHS]]) of episodes from the [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]] animated television series ''[[Dora the Explorer]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdempire.com/Exec/v5_search_item.asp?userid=99366341647249&string=dora+the+explorer&site_media_id=&site_id=4&pp=&used=0&search_refined=0|title=DVD Empire - Search - Titles - Dora the Explorer|accessdate=2008-06-03}}{{cite web|url=http://shop.nickjr.com/family/index.jsp?categoryId=1309371&cp=1029107|title=The Nickelodeon Shop - Dora the Explorer: DVDs and Videos|accessdate=2008-06-03}}{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/s/?ie=UTF8&rh=n%3A130%2Cn%3A163414%2Cn%3A292345%2Cn%3A13587401|title=Amazon.com: Dora the Explorer: Movies & TV|accessdate=2008-06-03}}{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/s/?ie=UTF8&rh=n%3A404272%2Cn%3A132%2Cn%3A574558|title=Amazon.com: Dora the Explorer: Video|accessdate=2008-06-03}} ==Specials== "Dora the Explorer" special releases include DVD [[box set|boxed sets]] (compilation of compilations) and samplers (i.e., a selection of episodes from various Nickelodeon shows). Excluded are: * shrinkwrapped twin packs (not boxed sets) * [[Nick Jr. (block)|Nick Jr.]] Favorites boxed sets * crossover episodes (i.e., [[Go, Diego, Go!]]) * Full length (52min) feature Dora's Christmas Carol Adventure (2009) {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{orphan|date=April 2012}}
'''Master the Mainframe contest''' is a [[Mainframe computer|mainframe]] [[Computer programming|programming]] challenge that is organized annually by IBM Academic Initiative System z.<ref name=Salamone>{{cite web|last=Salamone|first=Salvatore|title=It's Now Cool to Master the Mainframe|url=http://www.smartertechnology.com/c/a/Technology-For-Change/Its-Now-Cool-to-Master-the-Mainframe|accessdate=10 January 2012}}</ref>
== History ==
Originally catered to students attending [[North America]]n institutions of higher learning ([[United States|US]] and [[Canada]], excluding [[Quebec]]), the contest is currently running in separate countries across the globe (30 to date).<ref name=Todd>{{cite web |last1=Todd |first1=Mike |title=Master the Mainframe Contest: Past, Present and Future|url=http://ecc.marist.edu/conf2011/materials/NewtonMaster_the_Mainframe_-_Past,_Present_and_Future_v3.pdf|publisher=ECC 2011|accessdate=10 January 2012 |author2=Newton, P|page=8}}</ref> The goal of the contest is to provide students with the opportunity to experience working with mainframes.<ref name=Tood2>{{cite web |last1=Todd |first1=Mike |title=Master the Mainframe Contest: Past, Present and Future|url=http://ecc.marist.edu/conf2011/materials/NewtonMaster_the_Mainframe_-_Past,_Present_and_Future_v3.pdf|publisher=ECC 2011|accessdate=10 January 2012 |author2=Newton, P|pages=3–4}}</ref> The contest was created in part to increase the number of mainframe skilled individuals in the [[computing]] workforce.<ref name=Sharma>{{cite web|last=Sharma|first=Niranjan|title=IBM Academic Initiative Helps Fill the Skills Gap|url=http://destinationz.org/Community/Evangelizing-Mainframe/October-2011/IBM-Academic-Initiative-Helps-Fill-the-Skills-Gap.aspx|accessdate=10 January 2012}}</ref> The North American contest has successfully completed 7 contests to date.
== Contest ==
The contest that runs for North America typically starts during the Fall semester and runs until the end of December. It is separated into 3 parts in which each part increases in complexity. Part 1 introduces the contestants to the basic aspects necessary to get started with mainframe technologies and requires minimal time to complete. Part 2 on the other hand involves more steps for each tasks and usually takes a day or so to accomplish. The first 60 winners of Part 2 will receive monetary prize in recognition of their achievement. Lastly, part 3 is more in depth and may involve multiple programming challenges such as [[COBOL]], [[REXX]], [[Job Control Language|JCL]], etc. (depending on the questions set for the year's challenge).<ref name=Todd3>{{cite web |last1=Todd |first1=Mike |title=Master the Mainframe Contest: Past, Present and Futur|url=http://ecc.marist.edu/conf2011/materials/NewtonMaster_the_Mainframe_-_Past,_Present_and_Future_v3.pdf|publisher=ECC 2011|accessdate=11 January 2012 |author2=Newton, P}}</ref>
== Prizes ==
Past winners of Part 3 have receive gifts such as [[iPad]], [[iPod]], laptops or netbooks. Winners also receives an all expense paid trip to the [[IBM]] mainframe facility in [[Poughkeepsie, New York]].
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links ==
{{Portal|Information technology}}
* [https://www.ibm.com/it-infrastructure/z/education/academic IBM Z Academic Initiative program]
* [https://www.ibm.com/it-infrastructure/z/education/master-the-mainframe IBM Master the Mainframe Contest and Learning System ]
[[Category:Competitions]] [[Category:Mainframe computers| ]]

revision.text:
{{redirect|Pogs||POG (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox game | name = Pogs | image = | caption = | other_names = {{ubl|Milk caps|SkyCaps|Hero Caps|Flipper Caps|Pog Slammers}} | years = | genre = | players = | ages = | setup_time = | playing_time = | random_chance = | skills = }} '''Pogs''', generically called '''milk caps''', is a [[game]] that was popular among children during the mid 1990s.
The brand name "Pog" is owned by the World Pog Federation. The name pog originates from [[POG (drink)|POG]], a brand of juice made from [[passionfruit]], [[orange (fruit)|orange]], and [[guava]]; the use of POG bottle caps to play the game preceded the game's commercialization.<ref name=Lewis-23>Lewis, Tommi: "Pogs: The Milkcap Guide", page 23. Andrews and McMeel, 1994</ref>
==History== [[File:Men'uchi.jpg|thumb|''Men'uchi'' from the [[Edo period]] were made from clay. They were converted into paper format (''[[menko]]'') during the [[Meiji period]].]] The game of milk caps possibly originated in Maui, [[Hawaii]] during the 1920s or 1930s,<ref name="Air Force Print News"/><ref name="Business Wire">{{cite news|title=POG Is Back!; Funrise Heads to Hawaii Where It All Began to Re-Introduce the International Collectible Craze of the 90s |publisher=Business Wire |date=2005-12-05 |url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2005_Dec_13/ai_n15932949 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016184132/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2005_Dec_13/ai_n15932949 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-10-16 |accessdate=2007-02-17 }}</ref> or possibly with origins in [[Menko]], a Japanese card game very similar to milk caps, which has been in existence since the [[Edo period|17th century]].<ref name="Virginian Pilot">{{cite news | title = Flipping out pogs are popping up everywhere as the game that is sweeping through the nation catches on with South Hampton Roads youngsters |work=The Virginian Pilot | publisher = Landmark Communications, Inc.) | date = 1995-03-07 | url = http://scholar.lib.vt.edu/VA-news/VA-Pilot/issues/1995/vp950307/03070454.htm | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071016183510/http://scholar.lib.vt.edu/VA-news/VA-Pilot/issues/1995/vp950307/03070454.htm | archivedate = 2007-10-16 | accessdate = 2007-02-17 }}</ref> The game of milk caps was played on the Hawaiian island of [[Maui]] as early as 1927.<ref name="Essoyan">{{cite news |title=New wave of 'pog' mania crests over Hawaii |author=Essoyan, Susan |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=June 7, 1993 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-06-07/news/mn-611_1_milk-cover |accessdate=2 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=POG is newest kids' fad |author=Rothman, Jason |newspaper=Palo Alto Online |date=November 2, 1994 |url=http://www.paloaltoonline.com/weekly/morgue/news/1994_Nov_2.POG.html |accessdate=2 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Blossom Galbiso |author= |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun |date=December 31, 1994 |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1994-12-31/news/1994365103_1_pogs-liuzzo-civil-rights |accessdate=2 July 2010}}</ref> There are cap collectors that have dating till 1940s and 1950s.<ref name=hc>{{cite web|url=http://articles.courant.com/1993-07-26/features/0000006874_1_new-caps-milk-bottle-caps-comic-books |title=Will Cardboard Caps From Milk Bottles Become Cream Of All |publisher=Hartford Courant |date=1993-07-26 |accessdate=2016-06-03}}</ref>
Haleakala Dairy of Maui sold a mixed fruit drink in a glass bottle with a cap under the brand name of [[POG (drink)|POG]]. In 1955, Haleakala discontinued using the glass containers, but continued making the caps to allow the game to be played.<ref name=hc/> Orchards Hawaii also continued to make milk caps after having stopped using glass bottles.<ref name="nyt" /> In 1991, Haleakala expanded to the more populated Oahu island, which led to a revival of the game. With this revival, the Pog name began being used generically for the game.<ref name=hc/>
The 1990s revival is credited to Blossom Galbiso, a teacher and guidance counselor who taught at [[Waialua, Hawaii|Waialua Elementary School]] in [[Oahu]]. In 1991, Galbiso introduced the game she had played as a little girl to a new generation of students, soon incorporating milk caps into her fifth grade curriculum as a way of teaching math and as a nonviolent alternative to other popular schoolyard games, such as [[dodgeball]].<ref name="Essoyan"/> The game quickly spread from Oahu's [[North Shore (Oahu)|North Shore]], and by early 1992, STANPAC Inc., the small Canadian packaging company that had been manufacturing the milk caps distributed by Haleakala Dairy on Maui (the same caps that were collected by Galbiso for her class), was printing millions of milk caps every week for shipment to the Hawaiian island chain. The game soon spread to the mainland, first surfacing in California, Texas, Oregon, and Washington before spreading to the rest of the country. By 1993, the previously obscure game of milk caps, which had almost been forgotten, was now played throughout the world.<ref>{{cite news |title=It Was Hot In Hawaii, It's Ho-hum Here |author=Imperiale, Nancy |newspaper=Orlando Sentinel |date=March 15, 1994 |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1994-03-15/lifestyle/9403130497_1_pogs-hawaii-cardboard |accessdate=2 July 2010}}</ref> [[Image:Pogslam.jpg|thumb|250px|Real milk caps had small staples in them which, when stacked, produced a random element to the game. Regular milk caps were used to throw at the stack and were able to flip the pile.]]
Milk caps returned to popularity when the World POG Federation and the [[Canada Games Company]] reintroduced them under the Pog brand name in the 1990s. The Pog [[fad]] soared, and peaked in the mid-1990s.<ref>DeMasters, Tiffany. [https://web.archive.org/web/20100412015022/http://www.deseretnews.com/article/1%2C5143%2C640192788%2C00.html "90s pog fad still has a few die-hard fans"], ''[[Deseret News]]'', July 11, 2006. Accessed July 29, 2009.</ref><ref>Angilly, Paul. [http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=10734653&BRD=1641&PAG=461&dept_id=17739&rfi=6 "There was some good, some bad from 1993"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608015608/http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=10734653&BRD=1641&PAG=461&dept_id=17739&rfi=6 |date=2011-06-08 }}, ''The New Britain Herald'', December 31, 2003. Accessed July 29, 2009.</ref> Pogs were being handed out for opening bank accounts and in McDonald's Happy Meals.<ref name=hc/> With the end of the Pogs fad, Canada Games went out of business in 1997.
Seven other companies entered the milk cap field after a comic book and card industry convention in January 1993. [[SkyBox International]] and Marvel added the product to their lines under the names SkyCaps and Hero Caps respectively.<ref name=hc/> The game had spread to California, Florida and Texas.<ref name=nyt>{{cite news|title=Agreement Puts an End To 'Pog' Trademark War|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/09/us/agreement-puts-an-end-to-pog-trademark-war.html|accessdate=November 22, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=November 9, 1994}}</ref>
The term Pog was claimed as trademark by the World Pog Federation while other companies claimed it was generic term as it was selected by the children that played the game. In October 1994, a lawsuit was settled between World Pog and Universal Pogs Association. Pog was recognized as World Pog's exclusive term and Universal Pogs changed its name to Universal Slammers, Inc.<ref name=nyt/>
Because many children would keep the milk caps they won in games from other players, many school districts considered milk caps a form of gambling.<ref name="Virginian Pilot" /><ref name="GPro68">{{cite journal|last= |first= |title=Milking the MK Craze|journal=[[GamePro]]|issue=68 |publisher=[[International Data Group|IDG]]|date=March 1995|pages=154–155}}</ref> Milk caps proved to be major distractions from classes and the source of various playground arguments. These elements eventually led to the banning of milk caps from various schools across North America.<ref name="GPro68"/><ref name="Stay Free">{{Cite news | title=If You Can't Beat 'Em, Ban 'Em | newspaper=Stay Free! | issue=13 | date=April 1997 | url=http://www.stayfreemagazine.org/archives/13/banned.html | postscript=<!--None--> }}</ref> Other bannings occurred across Australia.<ref>''Pogs: The Milkcap Guide'', "invented by Laura Donahue" chapter 7. Andrews and McMeel, 1994</ref>
== Equipment == Milk caps generally involves two types of playing discs: milk caps and slammers. Milk caps are typically flat circular cardboard discs which are decorated with images on one or both sides. Traditional (or traditional-style) milk caps are made of rougher cardboard, are printed with limited colors, and often have a [[staple (fastener)|staple]] in them (as they appeared when used as actual POG bottlecaps), while modern commercial pogs were stiffer, thicker and are often printed with colorful glossy imagery.
The other equipment that is used is a slammer: a heavier game piece often made of metal, rubber, or more commonly plastic, which come in various thicknesses and weights. <ref name="Virginian Pilot" /> They are typically similar in diameter to milk caps. Metal slammers are not allowed in some games because they are usually heavier than other materials, giving the player with the first turn an unfair advantage, and have a tendency to damage the milk caps.
== Gameplay == [[File:Kids playing pog.jpeg|thumb|Children in the Philippines playing pogs.]] Rules vary among players, but the game variants generally have common gameplay features. Each player has his/her own collection of milk caps and one or more slammers. Before the game, players decide whether or not to play "for keeps", i.e. players get to keep the milk caps that they win during the game and must forfeit those that have been won by other players. The game can then begin as follows:
# The players each contribute an equal number of milk caps to build a stack with the pieces face-down, which will be used during the game.<ref name="Virginian Pilot" /> # The players take turns throwing their slammer down onto the top of the stack, causing it to spring up and the milk caps to scatter. Each player keeps any milk caps that land face-up after they have thrown.<ref name="Virginian Pilot" /><ref name="milkcapmania">{{cite web |title = How to Play pogs |url = http://www.milkcapmania.co.uk/howtoplay.html |accessdate = 2007-02-17 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070716215117/http://www.milkcapmania.co.uk/howtoplay.html |archivedate = 2007-07-16 |df = }}</ref> # After each throw, the milk caps which have landed face-down are then re-stacked for the next player. # When no milk caps remain in the stack, the player with the most pogs is the winner.<ref name="Virginian Pilot" />
== World POG Federation == The World POG Federation was the licensed POG publisher, which was 14% owned by Haleakala Dairy, the trademark holder of POGs. Federation president in 1994 was Alan Rypinski. The company was based in Costa Mesa, California.<ref name=nyt/>
==Military uses==
The [[Army and Air Force Exchange Service]], the [[United States Department of Defense]]'s largest and oldest exchange system, distributes milk-cap-like [[coin]]age as change at its stores in contingency areas (those supporting Operations [[Operation Enduring Freedom|Enduring Freedom]] and [[Operation Iraqi Freedom|Iraqi Freedom]]).<ref name="Stars and Stripes">{{cite web | title = Why pogs and not legal tender? | publisher = Stars and Stripes (Pacific Edition) | date = 2007-02-06 | url = http://www.stripes.com/news/why-pogs-and-not-legal-tender-1.59898 | format = website | accessdate = 2007-02-17 }} </ref> The reason for adopting milk caps as currency was that supply flights overseas had limited capacity and air-freight shipping involved high costs.<ref name="Air Force Print News">{{cite news | title = POGs – dollars, cents of setting up shop in a war zone | publisher = Air Force Print News Today | date = 2005-06-06 | url = http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2005/06/mil-050606-afpn04.htm | accessdate = 2007-02-17 }}</ref> Metal coinage weighs significantly more than paper milk caps, which are also much thinner than standard milk caps. While they are only issued in contingency areas, they are redeemable at any AAFES store worldwide.<ref name="Stars and Stripes" />
== Global variants == [[File:Menko-square-circle-collection.jpg|thumb|left|A collection of Menko cards.]]
=== Japan === {{main|Menko}} Menko (めんこ, 面子) is a Japanese card game played by two or more players, dating back to the 17th century. Each player uses Menko cards made from thick paper or cardboard, printed on one or both sides with images from anime, manga, and other works.
=== South Korea === [[File:Korean Play Takji.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Folding a ttakji from square paper.]] The card used in ''ttakji'' or ''ddakji'' ([[:ko:딱지 (장난감)|딱지]]) is constructed by folding two square pieces of paper together into a square. As with milk caps, the game is won by flipping the other player's card. The popular Korean variety show ''[[Running Man (TV series)|Running Man]]'' occasionally features ddakji in its missions, which may contribute to the awareness of the game in other parts of the world.<ref name="talty">{{cite book|last1=Talty|first1=Stephan|title=Under the Same Sky: From Starvation in North Korea to Salvation in America|date=2015|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|isbn=0544373170|page=10|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=91hCCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA10&lpg=PA10|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref><ref name="yi">{{cite book|last1=Yi|first1=I-hwa|title=Korea's Pastimes and Customs: A Social History|date=2006|publisher=Homa & Sekey Books|isbn=1931907382|page=58|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HcsMRc6pbQoC&pg=PA58|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref>
=== China === It is known in China as ''hua pian'' ({{zh|畫片}}) (also called ''yang pian'' in northern China)<ref>{{cite web|title=Yang Pian|url=http://baike.baidu.com/view/1328709.htm|publisher=Baidu}}</ref> and is printed on rectangular or circular cards.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hua Pian|url=http://baike.baidu.com/view/1206449.htm|publisher=Baidu}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Tazos]] * [[Marvel Disk Wars: The Avengers#Bachicombat|Bachicombat]] * [[Slammer Whammers]]
== References == {{Clear}} {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://spakatak.com/tazos/index.php spakatak.com International Tazos Guide] * [http://numispedia.org/AAFES/ Reference site for AAFES pogs, with image galleries] * [http://www.milkcapmania.co.uk/ Information and images of pogs, tazos, flippos and other milkcaps]
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox company | name = Mimimi Productions | logo = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = de | type = | traded_as = | ISIN = | industry = [[Video game industry]] | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{start date and age|df=yes|January 2011}} | founder = Dominik Abé
Johannes Roth | defunct = | location_city = [[Munich]] | location_country = [[Germany]] | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | products = ''[[The Last Tinker: City of Colors|The Last Tinker]]''
''[[Shadow Tactics: Blades of the Shogun|Shadow Tactics]]'' | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | num_employees = 19 | website = [http://www.mimimi-productions.de/ mimimi-productions.de] }} '''Mimimi Productions''' is a German [[video game]] software development company based in [[Munich]]. They are known for developing the [[platforming game]] ''[[The Last Tinker: City of Colors]]''{{cite web |last=Podolsky |first=Andrew |date=6 March 2014 |url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/03/06/the-last-tinker-city-of-colors-is-an-artistic-platformer-with-a-handmade-feel-preview/ |title=The Last Tinker: City of Colors is an artistic platformer with a handmade feel (preview) |publisher=[[VentureBeat]] |accessdate=20 April 2014}} and the [[real-time tactics]] game ''[[Shadow Tactics: Blades of the Shogun]]'',{{cite web| url=http://www.pcgamer.com/shadow-tactics-blades-of-the-shogun-demo-now-available-on-steam-and-gog/| title=Shadow Tactics: Blades of the Shogun demo now available on Steam and GOG| publisher=[[PC Gamer]]| date= 2016-11-21|| accessdate=2016-11-27}} which was released in December 2016. The company is currently developing ''Desperados III'', which is set to be released for Windows, PlayStation 4 and Xbox One, published by [[THQ Nordic]].{{cite web|url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-08-21-tactical-wild-west-series-desperados-returns-in-2019|title=Tactical Wild West series Desperados returns in 2019|first=Robert|last=Purchese|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=August 21, 2018|accessdate=August 21, 2018}} ==Games== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = National Public Gardens Day |type = Cultural |observedby = North America |significance = Celebrate and Recognize Botanic Gardens, Arboreta, and Public Gardens |date = Friday before Mother's Day (second Sunday in May) |celebrations = Over 600 member gardens throughout North America |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual }}
'''National Public Gardens Day''', occurring annually on the Friday before [[Mother's Day]], is a day to promote awareness of [[botanic gardens]], [[arboreta]], [[zoos]], historic gardens, or any of North America's [[public gardens]]. The day was established by the American Public Gardens Association, a [[Pennsylvania]] non-profit organization that supports, resources and promotes public gardens in North America.<ref>The American Public Gardens Association, ''American Public Gardens Association to Designate May 7, 2010 as the Second Annual National Public Gardens Day'', [http://www.publicgardens.org/web/2009/10/american_public_gardens_associat.aspx APGA Press Release], 2010.</ref>
==Activities== Members of the [[American Public Gardens Association]] celebrated National Public Gardens Day beginning in 2009 with activities that varied by garden. The [[Atlanta Botanical Garden]] invited visitors to bring flowers, so that they could be put into arrangements for patients and their families at Children's Hospital<ref>Atlanta On The Cheap. "50% off Admission to the Atlanta Botanical Garden on Friday & Gardens for Connoisseurs Tour this Weekend", [http://www.atlantaonthecheap.com/2009/05/07/50-off-admission-to-the-atlanta-botanical-garden-on-friday-gardens-for-connoisseurs-tour-this-weekend/].</ref> The [[Desert Botanical Garden]] in [[Phoenix, Arizona]], asked visitors to pledge to conserve water, displaying 400 five-gallon water containers that pledgers could adopt.<ref>[http://www.abc15.com/dpp/weather/weather_news/Desert-Botanical-Garden-joins-National-Public-Gardens-Day ABC 15. "Desert Botanical Garden joins National Public Gardens Day."]</ref> National spokesperson [[Paul James (gardener)|Paul James]] visited media gardens, speaking with the public and media about the role public gardens play in the local community.<ref>LaCrosse Tribune. "Don't Overlook Public Gardens." [http://lacrossetribune.com/lifestyles/home-and-garden/article_0014c3d2-47e6-11df-a78b-001cc4c03286.html].</ref>
In 2010, Senator [[Dick Durbin]] of Illinois spoke on the floor of the U.S. Senate about the importance of recognizing National Public Gardens Day, listing the [[US Botanic Garden]] and gardens in [[Illinois]] as examples.<ref>Congressional Record S3353. Recognizing National Public Gardens Day. May 6, 2010.</ref>
==History== Created in 2009, in partnership with sponsor, [[Rain Bird]], as a way to increase public awareness of the educational resources public gardens provide to local communities, National Public Gardens Day was adopted by the members of the American Public Gardens Association, to highlight programs such as plant conservation, [[water conservation]], the preservation of green spaces, and [[home gardening]].
The national spokesperson for National Public Gardens Day was [[Paul James (gardener)|Paul James]], host of [[HGTV]]'s Gardening By The Yard.
== Recognition == National Public Gardens Day has been recognized by various levels of government: *The City of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania<ref>The Office of Mayor Michael A. Nutter, The City of Philadelphia, ''National Public Gardens Day Proclamation," May 8, 2009.</ref> *The City of [[Dallas]], Texas<ref>The Office of Mayor Tom Leppert, The City of Dallas, "National Public Gardens Day Proclamation," May 8, 2009.</ref> *The City of [[Belmont, North Carolina]]<ref>Daniel Stowe Botanical Garden, [http://www.dsbg.org/news_detail.php?id=356#title Daniel Stowe Botanical Garden]</ref> *The State of [[Delaware]]<ref>The Office of the Governor, Jack A. Markell, The State of Delaware, "National Public Gardens Day Proclamation," May 8, 2009.</ref> *The Town of [[Framingham, Massachusetts]]<ref>The Office of the Town Manager, The Town of Framingham, "National Public Gardens Day Proclamation," May 8, 2009.</ref> *The State of [[California]], State Assembly<ref>State Assembly Member Adams, California State Assembly, "[http://dsf.chesco.org/chesco/lib/chesco/commissioners/pdf/commin_043009.pdf House Resolution #13]", May 8. 2009.</ref> *The State of California, Governor's Office<ref>The Office of Governor Arnold Swcharzenegger, The State of California, "Commendation of National Public Gardens Day," May 8, 2009.</ref> *The State of [[Florida]]<ref>The Florida State Senate, [http://www.flsenate.gov/Session/index.cfm?Mode=Bills&SubMenu=1&Tab=session&BI_Mode=ViewBillInfo&BillNum=2816&Chamber=Senate&Year=2010 Senate 2816: Relating to National Public Gardens Day], 2010.</ref> *The United States Congress<ref>The Architect of the Capital, Resolution for National Public Gardens Day, US Congress, 2010.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.nationalpublicgardensday.org|National Public Gardens Day official website}} *[http://www.publicgardens.org American Public Gardens Association] *[https://twitter.com/NPGD National Public Gardens Day on Twitter] *[http://www.facebook.com/nationalpublicgardensday National Public Gardens Day on Facebook]

{{Infobox website | name = PhysicsOverflow | logo = File:PhysicsOverflow Logo.svg | url = {{Official URL}} | commercial = No | registration = Optional | type = [[Question and answer website|Question and answer]]
[[Scholarly peer review#Postpublication|Open peer review]] | owner = Roger Cattin{{cite web |title = Legal |url = http://whois.domaintools.com/physicsoverflow.org |publisher = Roger Cattin|date = 2014-01-28 |accessdate = 2017-03-22 |work = PhysicsOverflow}} | author = Abhimanyu Pallavi Sudhir, Rahel Knoepfel and Roger Cattin | launch date = {{start date and age|2014|4}}| content_license = User contributions under [[Creative Commons license|CC BY-SA]] 3.0 }} '''PhysicsOverflow''' is a [[physics]] website that serves as a [[Scholarly peer review#Postpublication|post-publication open peer review]]https://physicsoverflow.org/faq platform for [[academic paper|research papers]] in physics, as well as a [[collaborative blog]] and [[online community]] of physicists. It allows users to ask, answer and comment on graduate-level physics questions, post and review manuscripts from [[ArXiv]] (which lists PhysicsOverflow discussion pages among its trackbackshttps://physicsoverflow.org/30425/we-have-arxiv-trackbacks?show=30425#q30425) and other sources, and vote on both forms of content. In addition to the two primary forms of content, the PhysicsOverflow community also welcomes discussions on [[List of unsolved problems in physics|unsolved problems]], and hosts a chat section for discussions on topics generally of interest to physicists and students of physics, such as those related to recent events in physics, physics academia, and the publishing process. ==History== PhysicsOverflow was started in April 2014 as a physics-equivalent of [[MathOverflow]] by Rahel Knöpfel, a physics PhD at the [[University of Rostock]], high-school student Abhimanyu Pallavi Sudhir, and Roger Cattin, a retired professor of computer science at the [[Fachhochschule|University of Applied Sciences, Switzerland]]. The site was initially a mere question-and-answer forum, as it was started by users dissatisfied by the policies of the [[Stack Exchange|Physics Stack Exchange]], but it was eventually expanded to include a ''Reviews'' section in October 2014.https://physicsoverflow.org/24235/the-reviews-section-is-out-of-beta ==Moderation practices== PhysicsOverflow is well-known for its liberal moderation policy and hesitation to block contributors except for spam, as reflected in the website's bill of "user rights".https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/6196/what-is-physics-overflow-and-how-is-it-linked-to-physics-sehttps://physicsoverflow.org/user-rights The content is largely community-moderated, much like MathOverflow, although exceptions have been recorded.https://physicsoverflow.org/31863/violation-of-policy-to-close-questionshttps://physicsoverflow.org/review Although the site's moderation policy is publicly available as part of the [https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B_ra1Ss1E-rWN3cyRC1zalAtT1U/edit moderator manual], the site has been criticised for the excessive dispersion of policy-related material, such as the [https://physicsoverflow.org/faq FAQ], [https://physicsoverflow.org/user-rights the Bill of Rights], [https://physicsoverflow.org/users/special the moderator list] and the [https://physicsoverflow.org/review Community Moderation threads], leading to reduced transparency.https://physics.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/6196/what-is-physics-overflow-and-how-is-it-linked-to-physics-se#comment25091_6213https://physicsoverflow.org/22268/physics-overflow-moderators-what-their-exact-role-and-powers In response, the site's administrators posted a bulletin of all moderation-related content on the site on the homepage. ==Technical details== {{external links|section|date=June 2017}} [[File:PhysicsOverflow Discus.svg|thumb|right|The PhysicsOverflow [[discus]] as it appears in the PhysicsOverflow logo.]] PhysicsOverflow runs [[Q&A software#Comparison of Q&A software|Question2Answer]], an open-source Q&A software, with a custom theme and several plugins and patches. Some of its plugins have been used by other Question2Answer websites, such as the [https://openscience.uni-bielefeld.de Open Science Q&A] and the [http://physics.qandaexchange.com/ Physics Problems Q&A].https://openscience.uni-bielefeld.de/768/how-do-i-regain-access-to-my-imported-accounthttps://blog.wikimedia.de/author/christopher_schwarzkopf/ ==Usage== [[Quantcast]] records around 3000 monthly visitors and between 20,000 and 50,000 global page views to PhysicsOverflow every month, over half of whom are located in four countries: the United States (26.8%), India (9.2%), the United Kingdom (8.5%), and Germany (6.4%).https://www.quantcast.com/physicsoverflow.org?country=CN However, according to PhysicsOverflow's own data, only around 1500 users actually contribute content to the site, and 440 are active at a given point in time.https://physicsoverflow.org/statistics ==Recognition== The creation of PhysicsOverflow was well-received by the [[MathOverflow]] community.http://meta.mathoverflow.net/questions/1608/physicsoverflow-just-went-live PhysicsOverflow was also featured at the 5th Offtopicariumhttps://physicsoverflow.org/22788/we-have-a-talk-at-the-offtopicarium?show=22788#q22788 and [[World Scientific]]'s Asia-Pacific Physics News Letter.http://www.worldscientific.com/doi/abs/10.1142/S2251158X15000193 * [[John Baez]] suggested the website as a platform for discussing research-level physics questions.http://math.ucr.edu/home/baez/books.html * Greg Bernhardt, the founder of PhysicsForums, acknowledged the site as a "very interesting development for the physics discussion communities".http://motls.blogspot.in/2013/08/discussion-on-old-and-new-theoretical.html?m=1 * Arnold Neumaier, a professor at the University of Vienna, employs PhysicsOverflow as the platform for discussion about his Theoretical Physics FAQ.http://www.mat.univie.ac.at/~neum/physfaq/physics-faq.html * String theorist [[Lubos Motl]] referred to the website as a "very promising competition [to Physics Stack Exchange]".http://motls.blogspot.in/2014/05/physics-overflow-is-live.html * The [[University of Stavenger]]'s cosmology department commented that PhysicsOverflow "seems to implement some interesting ideas", and that "it makes some sense the {{sic}} review the reviewing process".https://www.facebook.com/uiscosmology/posts/1228470267242602 * [[Urs Schreiber]] publicised the site, claiming it could act as a catalyst to make physics academia more open like mathematics.https://plus.google.com/+UrsSchreiber/posts/SoWhSAqmUJ1https://www.quora.com/Whats-your-impression-of-PhysicsOverflow/answer/Sebastian-Schacher ==See also== * [[MathOverflow]] * [[Stack Exchange]] * [[nLab]] ==References== {{reflist|3}} [[Category:Physics websites]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2014]] [[Category:Question-and-answer websites]] [[Category:Creative Commons-licensed websites]] [[Category:Gamification]] [[Category:Peer review]] [[Category:Academic publishing]]

{{Original research|date=June 2013}} The '''politico-media complex''' ( '''PMC''', also referred to as the '''political-media complex''' ) is a name that has been given to the close, systematized, [[Symbiosis|symbiotic]]-like network<ref name="network">{{cite news |title=Hacking reveals power network|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14846456 |publisher=[[The BBC]]|date=September 13, 2011 |accessdate=November 15, 2011|quote=The story of the News of the World phone-hacking scandal has revealed a web of links between senior figures within politics, the police and the media. }}</ref> of relationships between a [[Sovereign state|state's]] [[politics|political]] and [[ruling class]]es, its [[media industry]], and any interactions with or dependencies upon [[interest group]]s with other domains and agencies, such as [[law]] (and its enforcement through the [[police]]<ref name="filkin">{{cite news |title=Filkin report: Police warned over press links|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-16411329 |publisher=[[The BBC]] |date=January 4, 2012 |accessdate=January 6, 2012|quote=The "close relationship" between parts of Scotland Yard and the media has caused "serious harm", a report says.}}</ref>), [[corporation]]s and the [[Multinational corporation|multinationals]]. The term PMC is often used to name, derogatively, the collusion between governments or individual politicians and the media industry in an attempt to manipulate rather than inform the people.<ref>Swanson, David L. "The Political-Media Complex at 50: Putting the 1996 Presidential Campaign in Context." ''American Behavioral Scientist'' 40 (1997): 1265.</ref><ref name="rawnsley">{{cite news |first=Andrew |last=Rawnsley |authorlink=Andrew Rawnsley |title=A conspiracy that threatens democracy |url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/2001election/story/0,8224,490003,00.html |work=[[The Observer]] |page=29 |date=May 13, 2001 |accessdate=September 19, 2011|quote=The politico-media complex has locked itself into a cycle where politicians and journalists feed each other's negativity.}}</ref><ref name="rentoul">{{cite news |first=John |last=Rentoul |authorlink=John Rentoul |title=John Rentoul: Whodunnit? Cameron, of course |url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/2001election/story/0,8224,490003,00.html |work=[[The Independent]] |date=January 8, 2006 |accessdate=September 21, 2011|quote=The key to understanding the Conservative revival, as it was to understanding the Blair bubble, is to know about the dynamics of the politico-media complex. Cameron wants to be written up as new and exciting. The media want to write him up as new and exciting, because that fits the template into which news reporting either fits or is made to fit.}}</ref><ref name="jenkins">{{cite news|first=Simon|last=Jenkins|authorlink=Simon Jenkins|title=The weekend's 9/11 horror-fest will do Osama bin Laden's work for him|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/story/0,,1867405,00.html|work=[[The Guardian]]|page=36 |date=September 8, 2006|accessdate=September 19, 2011 |quote=This response has become 24-hour, seven-day-a-week amplification by the new politico-media complex, especially shrill where the dead are white people.}}</ref><ref name="symons">{{cite news|first=Emma-Kate|last=Symons|title=French culture in the dock over Strauss-Khan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/story/0,,1867405,00.html|work=[[The Australian]]|publisher=News Limited|date=June 13, 2011|accessdate=September 20, 2011 |quote=...French newspapers and magazine sales have skyrocketed as voters voraciously consume every detail of DSK's ([[Dominique Strauss-Khan]]) woes and digest the massive collateral damage his case has inflicted across their politico-media complex.}}</ref><ref name="lse1">{{cite web | title=Front Page Leveson: Papers lead with freedom the day after the Report | website=Media Policy Project | date=4 December 2012 | url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/mediapolicyproject/2012/12/04/front-page-leveson-papers-lead-with-freedom-the-day-after-the-report/ | access-date=2 August 2018}}</ref><ref name="lse2">{{cite web | title=The Day After Leveson: Newspapers covered more than just their own defence | website=Media Policy Project | date=5 December 2012 | url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/mediapolicyproject/2012/12/05/the-day-after-leveson-newspapers-covered-more-than-just-their-own-defense/ | access-date=2 August 2018}}</ref>
There is recent evidence to suggest that newer media portals (as opposed to those outlets of "traditional" [[mainstream media]] [MSM]) are turning, more readily, to using the PMC framework in critical analysis and interpretation of media behavior. One notable example of this is with regards to the [[Leveson Inquiry]].<ref name="lse0">{{cite web | title=Leveson: Bloggers vs the Press | website=Media Policy Project | date=7 December 2012 | url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/mediapolicyproject/2012/12/07/leveson-bloggers-vs-the-press/ | access-date=2 August 2018}}</ref>
[[File:The_Leveson_Love_Triangle_Leveson-2.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|The Leveson Love Triangle: Favours and reciprocities of the politico-media complex depicted by the [http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/mediapolicyproject/programme Media Policy Project] of the [[London School of Economics]]]]
==Early media institutions== Before [[Johannes Gutenberg]] invented movable type in 1450, most information was delivered by town criers, ministers from the pulpit, or bartenders. [[Town criers]] spread information and news including royal edicts, police regulations, important community events and war news. These early methods of communication were often delivered by messengers on foot, and could be easily controlled by the ruling class.<ref>{{cite book |title=American Media History |last=Fellow |first=Anthony |year=2005 |publisher=Michael Rosenberg |location=Boston, MA |isbn=978-0-495-56775-2 |page=1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7THGKyvBXScC&pg=PT19&dq=%22town+criers%22+polical+media&ei=3IgcS67kN57IzAT2k5iEDQ#v=onepage&q=&f=false}}</ref> With the invention of the printing press news began to be spread in writing. [[Corantos]], which were semi-regular pamphlets that reported news, are an example of the early politico-media complex. Popular in England, corantos reported mostly foreign news, as the royal government attempted to control what domestic news reached the masses. Corantos eventually would become regular periodicals that were subject to less political control, and mark one of the earlier forms of industrialized media.<ref>Patterson, Catherine. "Inventing the News." Engines of our Ingenuity. University of Houston. 2005. http://www.uh.edu/engines/epi1983.htm. Dec. 14, 2009.</ref>
==Print==
===Global print media=== The [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] states: "Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference, and impart information and ideas through any media regardless of frontiers".<ref>"The Universal Declaration of Human Rights". United Nations. 2009. [https://www.un.org/en/documents/udhr/ UN.org]</ref> Most of the international papers present in the world today are national papers re-edited for a wider audience.{{Citation needed|date=June 2013}} Because of this, there can be biases based on nationality.{{Synthesis inline|date=June 2013}} In any publication there is some sort of bias just from what news is covered and what stories are shown at the forefront of the publication.<ref>Tunstall, Jeremy. pg 12. The Media In Britain. 1983.</ref>{{Failed verification|date=June 2013}}
Although print media in the West has suffered from declining advertising trends,<ref name="printdecline">{{cite web | last=Fontevecchia | first=Agustino | title=New York Times Agonizes As Print Media Ad Revenues Continue To Slide | website=Forbes | date=12 September 2011 | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/afontevecchia/2011/09/12/new-york-times-agonizes-as-print-media-ad-revenues-continue-to-slide/ | access-date=2 August 2018}}</ref> many newspapers and magazines in the [[Middle East]] continue to do well.<ref>"Middle East Newspapers Struggle in New Age". October 26, 2009. [http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidDS261009_dsart58/Struggling%20Papers. Zawya.com]</ref> For countries in which the majority of the population does not have ready access to the Internet or television, newspapers and magazines are one of the few ways to get the news.<ref>Geography of the Third World. pg 303. Routledge. New York. 1996.</ref> However, the independence from political influence, and dependability of newsprint is questionable in many countries. The [[Reporters Without Borders]] [[Press Freedom Index]] suggests that even in many first world countries the rights of the press are not fully respected, and that the press is not completely free to investigate or criticize the government, though the situation is far worse in third world or politically unstable nations.{{Synthesis inline|date=June 2013}}<ref name="press freedom index">"Press Freedom Index 2009". [http://en.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_en.pdf RSF.org] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/616iLWBGp?url=http://en.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_en.pdf |date=2011-08-21 }}</ref>
====The West==== [[File:Newspapers-20080928.jpg|thumb|[[Newspapers]], as seen here, are easily available in many parts of the world.]]
Newspapers and magazines do have a back and forth between readers and journalists. Some studies have shown that the print media are more likely to reinforce existing political attitudes of the masses than change them.<ref>Byerly, Caroline. Ross, Karen. “Women and media: international perspectives”. Oxford: Blackwell Publishing Ltd. 2004.</ref>
Reporters Without Borders, an international [[non-governmental organization]] that promotes [[freedom of the press]], produces an annual [[Press Freedom Index]] assessing countries' press freedom. Reporters Without Borders secretary-general Jean-François Julliard said at the release of the 2009 Press Freedom Index, "It is disturbing to see European democracies such as France, Italy and Slovakia fall steadily in the rankings year after year [...] Europe should be setting an example as regards civil liberties. How can you condemn human rights violations abroad if you do not behave irreproachably at home? The Obama effect, which has enabled the United States to recover 16 places in the index, is not enough to reassure us."<ref name="press freedom index"/>
====Asia==== The press is censored in the People's Republic of China by the [[Golden Shield Project]], known colloquially as the [[Great Firewall of China]].<ref name=Norris>{{cite book |title=Public Sentinel: News Media and Governance Reform |last=Norris |first=Pippa |authorlink=Pippa Norris |author2=World Bank Staff |year=2009 |publisher=[[World Bank Publications]] |location= |isbn=978-0-8213-8200-4 |page=360 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xzFVxDDhfnkC&pg=PA360 |accessdate=11 January 2011}}</ref> ''Reporters Without Borders'' ranks [[Media of the People's Republic of China|China's press situation]] as "very serious," the worst possible ranking on their five-point scale.<ref>"The News by Country". Reporters Without Borders. Retrieved August 25, 2006</ref> China's press was ranked 173rd out of 179 countries in the 2013 World Press Freedom Index.<ref name="WPFI2013">{{cite web |url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013163532/http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf |archivedate=2015-10-13 |df= }}</ref> The Chinese government maintains the legal authority to [[Censorship|censor]] the press, and in defense of censorship claims that the Communist party in China has the most freedom of press, since there is no wealthy minority controlling it.<ref>"History of Publishing." Encyclopædia Britannica. November 2, 2009. [[Encyclopædia Britannica Online]].</ref>
====The Middle East and North Africa==== Middle Eastern print media is mainly paid for by private funders, either a specific family or specific government party.{{Citation needed|date=June 2013}} Some Middle Eastern newspapers and magazines have been accused of having obvious political ties.<ref>Lewis, Bernard. pg 11. The Middle East: A Brief History of the Last 2,000 Years. Britain. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. 1995.</ref> Many countries in the Middle East and Africa have harsh government restrictions as to what can be published when, for various reasons depending on political and economic circumstances.{{Synthesis inline|date=June 2013}} [[Censorship in Iran|Iran]], ranked 174 out of 179 in 2013, is described as highly censored, as the Iranian government maintains strict control over much of the print and broadcast media and news websites.<ref name="WPFI2013" /> Reporters Without Borders has said that journalists in [[Israel]] "enjoy real freedom of expression despite the existence of military censorship."<ref name="WPFI2013" /> However, Professor Yoram Peri of the [[University of Maryland]] has said that Israel experienced a media control crackdown as the government censors coverage of military action coverage, displaying how governments often limit press freedom during times of war.<ref>Peri, Yoram. Between Battles and Ballots: Israeli Military in Politics. pg 2. Press Syndicate of the University of Cambridge. 1983.</ref>{{Verify source|date=June 2013}} According to Reporters Without Borders in 2009, [[Eritrea]] in Northern Africa is the worst ranked country for journalistic freedom. Eritrea is currently a one-party "transitional government" which has yet to enact its ratified constitution.<ref>"Eritrea." The World Fact Book. The Central Intelligence Agency. https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/er.html</ref> Other African countries at the bottom of the 2009 Press Freedom Index include [[Syria]] (165) and [[Somalia]] (164).<ref name="press freedom index"/> Both countries exhibit little journalistic freedom, and are both known{{By whom|date=January 2015}} for their unstable transitional governments and near constant warfare.<ref>"Syria" & "Somalia." The World Fact Book. The Central Intelligence Agency. https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/sy.html & https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/so.html</ref>{{Failed verification|date=June 2013}}
===Struggles=== Where newspapers used to represent an exclusive connection between readers and advertisers, print media must now compete with the power of the entire Internet.<ref>Ivan, Robert. The Krugman Paradox: newspaper websites' inability to generate economically sustainable advertising revenue. New York University. Fall 2008. pg. 18.[http://metaprinter.com/Projects/Robert_Ivan_MAthesis_2008NYU.pdf MA Thesis PDF]</ref> Because of declining advertising revenue and shrinking audiences, [[print press]] has been described as declining.<ref name="printdecline" /> Today a little more than half of Americans read a newspaper every day. However, a 2004 report notes that 55 million newspapers are still sold daily in the United States,<ref>"The State of the News Media 2004". [http://stateofthemedia.org/2004/newspapers-intro/audience/ Stateofthemedia.org]</ref> and newsprint still plays a significant role in the politico-media complex.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chozick|first1=Amy|title=Conservative Koch Brothers Turning Focus to Newspapers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/21/business/media/koch-brothers-making-play-for-tribunes-newspapers.html|accessdate=9 April 2015|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=20 April 2013}}</ref>
In addition to economic struggles and readership decline, newsprint has also struggled with losing readers' trust. Surveys have found that people tend to trust newspapers less than other news media, in part because they believe that newspaper journalists are "isolated and out of touch" and motivated by commercial interests.<ref name="2004att">"The State of the News Media 2004". [http://stateofthemedia.org/2004/newspapers-intro/public-attitudes/ Stateofthemedia.org]</ref> Most people believe their local and national news television stations more than their local and national newspapers.<ref name="2004att" /> The only news medium that people trust less than newspapers is print magazines.<ref name="2004att" />
Some{{who|date=June 2013}} have speculated that the youth today are more visually inclined, and are therefore less likely to be influenced by written political news or propaganda.<ref name="2004att" /> One Pew Center study found that 28% of this generation read the paper on a given day, and average only 10 minutes of reading time. [[Harvard]] Professor Thomas Patterson has said: "What's happened over time is that we have become more of a viewing nation than a reading nation, and the internet is a little of both. My sense is that, like it or not, the future of news is going to be in the electronic media, but we don't really know what that form is going to look like."<ref>Jones, Juston. "Young Adults Are Giving Newspapers Scant Notice". July 16, 2007. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/16/business/media/16habits.html?_r=0 New York Times]</ref>
==Radio==
===History of political radio=== [[File:RCA Radiola 25 - raw.jpg|thumb|An [[Radio Corporation of America|RCA]] Radiola, manufactured 1925.]]
The early American radio industry was composed of commercial shipping companies that used radio for navigation, and amateur radio enthusiasts, who built radios at home.<ref>Craig, Douglas B. Fireside Politics: Radio and Political Culture in the United States. pg 26. The [[Johns Hopkins University Press]]. 2000.</ref> This mixture of military, industry and community went unregulated until the [[Radio Act of 1912]], which required all ships to use radio communication and keep a constant radio watch, amateur users to be licensed, and began regulating the use of wavelengths for radio transmissions.<ref>An Act to Regulate Radio Communication, August 13, 1912.</ref> This act represents one of the earliest interactions between the government and the radio media and also set a precedent for later radio legislation,{{OR|date=June 2013}} including the [[Radio Act of 1927]], which established the [[Federal Radio Commission]] and added further regulation to radio users, both commercial and amateur.<ref>Public Law No. 632, February 23, 1927, 69th Congress. An Act for the regulation of radio communications, and for other purposes.</ref> Government regulation increased again with the American entrance into World War I, when President Woodrow Wilson ordered naval control of all radio stations, and ordered that amateurs cease all radio activity. [[Jonathan Reed Winkler]], a noted WWI historian, said “It was only during World War I that the United States first came to comprehend how a strategic communications network-the collection of submarine telegraph cables, and long-distance radio stations used by a nation for diplomatic, commercial and military purposes- was vital to the global political and economic interests of a great power in the modern world.”<ref>Winkler, Jonathan Reed.
