revision.text:
{{Infobox book | italic title = Why Not Me? | name = Why Not Me? | image = Why_Not_Me_book_cover.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = [[Mindy Kaling]] | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United States]] | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = | genre = Memoir | set_in = | publisher = Crown Archetype | publisher2 = | pub_date = | english_pub_date = | published = | media_type = | pages = 240 | awards = | isbn = 978-0-8041-3814-7 | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = [[Is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me? (And Other Concerns)]] | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }} '''''Why Not Me?''''' is a 2015 humor book by actress and writer [[Mindy Kaling]].<ref name="pub">{{cite web |url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/9780804138147 |title= Why Not Me?|website=publishersweekly.com |publisher=Pushlishers Weekly |access-date=24 February 2018 |quote=}}</ref><ref name="washington">{{cite news |last=Chaney |first=Jen |date=9 September 2015 |title= Mindy Kaling’s new book ‘Why Not Me?’ reads like . . . Mindy Kaling|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/books/mindy-kalings-new-book-why-not-me-reads-like--mindy-kaling/2015/09/09/74561d10-565c-11e5-abe9-27d53f250b11_story.html |work= The Washington Post |location= |access-date= 24 February 2018}}</ref> The book consists mostly of humorous observational essays based on Kaling's life, and it also includes one chapter of fiction.<ref name="entertainment weekly">{{cite news |last= BIEDENHARN |first= ISABELLA |date= 14 September 2015|title= 'Why Not Me?' by Mindy Kaling: EW Review|url= http://ew.com/article/2015/09/14/why-not-me-mindy-kaling-ew-review/|work=Entertainment Weekly |location= |access-date= 24 February 2018}}</ref>
The book spent 16 weeks on the New York Times Best Sellers list.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/2016/01/24/hardcover-nonfiction |title= Hardcover Nonfiction - Best sellers |date=January 24, 2016 |website= nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times |access-date=24 February 2018}}</ref>
==Synopsis== The book is a collection of ancedotal essays written by Kaling about her experiences and observations about Hollywood.<ref name="pub" /> Carina Chocano of ''The New York Times'' noted that the book was "loosely fashioned around themes of approval and entitlement."<ref>{{cite news |last= Chocano|first=Carina |date=16 November 2015 |title= Mindy Kaling’s ‘Why Not Me?’|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/22/books/review/mindy-kalings-why-not-me.html?mtrref=www.google.es&gwh=B3B49854C935C6272DB911C9D0C716B3&gwt=pay|work= The New York Times |access-date= 24 February 2018}}</ref>
The book also contains a chapter that is a work of fiction about an alternative world where Kaling is a Latin teacher in a prep school on the Upper East Side of New York City.<ref name="entertainment weekly" />
The final chapter of the book is a transcript of Kaling's 2014 speech at [[Harvard Law School]].<ref name="entertainment weekly" />
==Reception== The book received mostly positive reviews. ''The Atlantic'' called the book "a defense of hard work."<ref>{{cite news |last=Garber |first=Megan |date= |title= Mindy Kaling Is Thirsty|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2015/09/mindy-kaling-is-thirsty/405160/ |work= The Atlantic |location= |access-date=24 February 2018 }}</ref> Publishers Weekly criticized the book for skirting major issues such as her mother's death and relationship with [[B. J. Novak]].<ref name="pub" />
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:2015 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Show business memoirs]] [[Category:Comedy books]] [[Category:Works by Mindy Kaling]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2601:543:4204:4456:A9A5:23A8:78DB:B149|2601:543:4204:4456:A9A5:23A8:78DB:B149]] ([[User talk:2601:543:4204:4456:A9A5:23A8:78DB:B149|talk]]) to last version by Donner60
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} [[File:Gorilla licking wound.jpg|right|thumb|A gorilla licking a wound]] '''Wound licking''' is an instinctive response in humans and many other animals to [[licking|lick]] an [[injury]]. Dogs, cats, small rodents, horses, and primates all lick wounds.<ref>{{cite book | last = Engel| first = Cindy | title = Wild Health: Lessons in Natural Wellness from the Animal Kingdom | publisher = Houghton Mifflin Harcourt | year = 2003| location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/?id=8FwqLh2a2ckC | doi = | id = | isbn = 9780618340682 }}</ref> [[Saliva]] contains [[tissue factor]] which promotes the [[blood coagulation|blood clotting mechanism]]. The enzyme [[lysozyme]] is found in many tissues and is known to attack the cell walls of many [[gram-positive bacteria]], aiding in defense against infection. Tears are also beneficial to wounds due to the lysozyme enzyme. However, there are also infection risks due to bacteria in the human mouth.
==Mechanism== [[File:Dog licking wound.jpg|right|thumb|A dog licking a wounded paw]] {{Further|Saliva#Disinfectants}} [[Oral mucosa]] heals faster than [[skin]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Szpaderska AM, Zuckerman JD, DiPietro LA |title=Differential Injury Responses in Oral Mucosal and Cutaneous Wounds |journal=J. Dent. Res. |volume=82 |issue=8 |pages=621–6 |date=August 2003 |pmid=12885847 |url=http://jdr.sagepub.com/cgi/reprint/82/8/621.pdf |doi=10.1177/154405910308200810}}</ref> suggesting that saliva may have properties that aid wound healing. Saliva [[Saliva#Contents|contains]] cell-derived [[tissue factor]], and many compounds that are [[antibacterial]] or promote healing. Salivary tissue factor, associated with [[microvesicles]] shed from cells in the mouth, promotes wound healing through the extrinsic [[blood coagulation]] cascade.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Glazko AJ, Greenberg DM | title=The mechanism of the action of saliva in blood coagulation|journal=Am J Physiol|year=1938|volume=125|pages=108–12}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Berckmans RJ, Sturk A, van Tienen LM, Schaap MC, Nieuwland R |title=Cell-derived vesicles exposing coagulant tissue factor in saliva|journal=Blood|year=2011|volume=117|pages=3172–80|doi=10.1182/blood-2010-06-290460}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Gross PL| title=Salivary microvesicles clot blood|journal=Blood|year=2011|volume=117|pages=2989|doi=10.1182/blood-2011-02-332759|pmid=21415275}}</ref> The [[enzymes]] [[lysozyme]] and [[peroxidase]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ihalin R, Loimaranta V, Tenovuo J |title=Origin, structure, and biological activities of peroxidases in human saliva |journal=Arch Biochem Biophys |volume=445 |issue=2 |pages=261–8 |date=January 2006 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WB5-4GSJTTV-3&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=3d612cf2a4938000d7788ebe7d1b4bcc |doi=10.1016/j.abb.2005.07.004 |pmid=16111647 }}</ref> [[defensin]]s,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Abiko Y, Nishimura M, Kaku T |title=Defensins in saliva and the salivary glands |journal=Med Electron Microsc |volume=36 |issue=4 |pages=247–52 |year=2003 |url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/hny6afgy5cxu1xw9/ |doi=10.1007/s00795-003-0225-0 |pmid=16228657}}</ref> [[cystatin]]s and an [[antibody]], [[IgA]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Schenkels LC, Veerman EC, Nieuw Amerongen AV |title=Biochemical composition of human saliva in relation to other mucosal fluids |journal=Crit. Rev. Oral Biol. Med. |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=161–75 |year=1995 |pmid=7548622 |url=http://cro.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/6/2/161 |doi=10.1177/10454411950060020501}}</ref> are all antibacterial. [[Thrombospondin]] and some other components are [[Antiviral protein|antiviral]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Campo J, Perea MA, del Romero J, Cano J, Hernando V, Bascones A |title=Oral transmission of HIV, reality or fiction? An update |journal=Oral Dis |volume=12 |issue=3 |pages=219–28 |date=May 2006 |pmid=16700731 |doi=10.1111/j.1601-0825.2005.01187.x |url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/118633302/abstract}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Baron S, Singh I, Chopra A, Coppenhaver D, Pan J |title=Innate antiviral defenses in body fluids and tissues |journal=Antiviral Res. |volume=48 |issue=2 |pages=71–89 |date=November 2000 |pmid=11114410 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6T2H-41WCDST-1&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=2797de97cbc00ea90268aa8bc9342b32 |doi=10.1016/S0166-3542(00)00126-1}}</ref> A [[Protease inhibitor (biology)|protease inhibitor]], [[secretory leukocyte protease inhibitor]], is present in saliva and is both antibacterial and antiviral, and a promoter of wound healing.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ashcroft GS, Lei K, Jin W, etal |title=Secretory leukocyte protease inhibitor mediates non-redundant functions necessary for normal wound healing |journal=Nat. Med. |volume=6 |issue=10 |pages=1147–53 |date=October 2000 |pmid=11017147 |doi=10.1038/80489 |url=http://www.nature.com/nm/journal/v6/n10/full/nm1000_1147.html}}</ref><ref>Kate Wong: [http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?id=a-proteins-healing-powers A Protein's Healing Powers]. ''Scientific American'' 2 October 2000</ref> [[Nitrates]] that are naturally found in saliva break down into [[nitric oxide]] on contact with [[skin]], which will inhibit [[bacterial growth]].<ref name=lancet>{{cite journal |vauthors=Benjamin N, Pattullo S, Weller R, Smith L, Ormerod A |title=Wound licking and nitric oxide |journal=Lancet |volume=349 |issue=9067 |pages=1776 |date=June 1997 |pmid=9193412 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(05)63002-4 |url=http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(05)63002-4/fulltext}}</ref> Saliva contains [[growth factors]]<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Zelles T, Purushotham KR, Macauley SP, Oxford GE, Humphreys-Beher MG |title=Saliva and growth factors: the fountain of youth resides in us all |journal=J. Dent. Res. |volume=74 |issue=12 |pages=1826–32 |date=December 1995 |pmid=8600176 |url=http://jdr.sagepub.com/cgi/reprint/74/12/1826.pdf |doi=10.1177/00220345950740120301}}</ref> such as [[epidermal growth factor]],<ref>{{cite journal |author=Jahovic N, Güzel E, Arbak S, Yeğen BC |title=The healing-promoting effect of saliva on skin burn is mediated by epidermal growth factor (EGF): role of the neutrophils |journal=Burns |volume=30 |issue=6 |pages=531–8 |date=September 2004 |pmid=15302417 |doi=10.1016/j.burns.2004.02.007 |url=http://www.journals.elsevierhealth.com/periodicals/jbur/article/PIIS0305417904000816/abstract}}</ref> [[Vascular endothelial growth factor|VEGF]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Pammer J, Weninger W, Mildner M, Burian M, Wojta J, Tschachler E |title=Vascular endothelial growth factor is constitutively expressed in normal human salivary glands and is secreted in the saliva of healthy individuals |journal=J. Pathol. |volume=186 |issue=2 |pages=186–91 |date=October 1998 |pmid=9924435 |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1096-9896(1998100)186:2<186::AID-PATH148>3.0.CO;2-J |url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/1260/abstract}}</ref> [[TGF beta 1|TGF-β1]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Schrementi ME, Ferreira AM, Zender C, DiPietro LA |title=Site-specific production of TGF-beta in oral mucosal and cutaneous wounds |journal=Wound Repair Regen |volume=16 |issue=1 |pages=80–6 |year=2008 |pmid=18086295 |doi=10.1111/j.1524-475X.2007.00320.x |url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/119413518/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0}}</ref> [[leptin]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Frank S, Stallmeyer B, Kämpfer H, Kolb N, Pfeilschifter J |title=Leptin enhances wound re-epithelialization and constitutes a direct function of leptin in skin repair |journal=J. Clin. Invest. |volume=106 |issue=4 |pages=501–9 |date=August 2000 |pmid=10953025 |pmc=380250 |doi=10.1172/JCI9148 |url=http://www.jci.org/articles/view/9148}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Gröschl M, Topf HG, Kratzsch J, Dötsch J, Rascher W, Rauh M |title=Salivary leptin induces increased expression of growth factors in oral keratinocytes |journal=J. Mol. Endocrinol. |volume=34 |issue=2 |pages=353–66 |date=April 2005 |pmid=15821102 |doi=10.1677/jme.1.01658 |url=http://jme.endocrinology-journals.org/cgi/content/full/34/2/353}}</ref> [[Insulin-like growth factor 1|IGF-I]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Costigan DC, Guyda HJ, Posner BI |title=Free insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) and IGF-II in human saliva |journal=J. Clin. Endocrinol. Metab. |volume=66 |issue=5 |pages=1014–8 |date=May 1988 |pmid=3360895 |doi=10.1210/jcem-66-5-1014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Todorović V, Pesko P, Micev M, etal |title=Insulin-like growth factor-I in wound healing of rat skin |journal=Regul. Pept. |volume=150 |issue=1–3 |pages=7–13 |date=October 2008 |pmid=18597865 |doi=10.1016/j.regpep.2008.05.006 |url=}}</ref> [[lysophosphatidic acid]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Sugiura T, Nakane S, Kishimoto S, Waku K, Yoshioka Y, Tokumura A |title=Lysophosphatidic acid, a growth factor-like lipid, in the saliva |journal=J. Lipid Res. |volume=43 |issue=12 |pages=2049–55 |date=December 2002 |pmid=12454265 |url=http://www.jlr.org/cgi/content/full/43/12/2049 |doi=10.1194/jlr.M200242-JLR200}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Balazs L, Okolicany J, Ferrebee M, Tolley B, Tigyi G |title=Topical application of the phospholipid growth factor lysophosphatidic acid promotes wound healing in vivo |journal=Am. J. Physiol. Regul. Integr. Comp. Physiol. |volume=280 |issue=2 |pages=R466–72 |date=1 February 2001|pmid=11208576 |url=http://ajpregu.physiology.org/cgi/content/abstract/280/2/R466 }}</ref> [[hyaluronan]]<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Pogrel MA, Low MA, Stern R |title=Hyaluronan (hyaluronic acid) and its regulation in human saliva by hyaluronidase and its inhibitors |journal=J Oral Sci |volume=45 |issue=2 |pages=85–91 |date=June 2003 |pmid=12930131 |url=http://jos.dent.nihon-u.ac.jp/journal/45/2/085.pdf |format=PDF |doi=10.2334/josnusd.45.85}}</ref> and [[Nerve Growth Factor|NGF]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Li AK, Koroly MJ, Schattenkerk ME, Malt RA, Young M |title=Nerve growth factor: acceleration of the rate of wound healing in mice |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=77 |issue=7 |pages=4379–81 |date=July 1980 |pmid=6933491 |pmc=349838 |doi=10.1073/pnas.77.7.4379 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kawamoto K, Matsuda H |title=Nerve growth factor and wound healing |journal=Prog. Brain Res. |volume=146 |issue= |pages=369–84 |year=2004 |pmid=14699974 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=bBmjiVUTsuEC&pg=PA369 |doi=10.1016/S0079-6123(03)46023-8 |isbn=978-0-444-51472-1 |series=Progress in Brain Research}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Nam JW, Chung JW, Kho HS, Chung SC, Kim YK |title=Nerve growth factor concentration in human saliva |journal=Oral Dis |volume=13 |issue=2 |pages=187–92 |date=March 2007 |pmid=17305621 |doi=10.1111/j.1601-0825.2006.01265.x |url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/118545038/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0}}</ref> which all promote healing, although levels of [[Epidermal growth factor|EGF]] and NGF in humans are much lower than those in rats. In humans, [[HTN1|histatins]] may play a larger role.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Oudhoff MJ, Bolscher JG, Nazmi K, etal |title=Histatins are the major wound-closure stimulating factors in human saliva as identified in a cell culture assay |journal=FASEB J. |volume=22 |issue=11 |pages=3805–12 |date=November 2008 |pmid=18650243 |doi=10.1096/fj.08-112003 |url=http://www.fasebj.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=18650243}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Wright K |title=Top 100 Stories of 2008 #62: Researchers Discover Why Wound-Licking Works |journal=Discover Magazine |date=28 December 2008 |url=http://discovermagazine.com/2009/jan/062}}</ref> As well as being growth factors, IGF-I and [[TGF alpha|TGF-α]] induce antimicrobial peptides.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Sørensen OE, Cowland JB, Theilgaard-Mönch K, Liu L, Ganz T, Borregaard N |title=Wound healing and expression of antimicrobial peptides/polypeptides in human keratinocytes, a consequence of common growth factors |journal=J. Immunol. |volume=170 |issue=11 |pages=5583–9 |date=1 June 2003|pmid=12759437 |url=http://www.jimmunol.org/cgi/content/full/170/11/5583#R31 |doi=10.4049/jimmunol.170.11.5583}}</ref> Saliva also contains an [[analgesic]], [[opiorphin]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Wisner A, Dufour E, Messaoudi M, etal |title=Human Opiorphin, a natural antinociceptive modulator of opioid-dependent pathways |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=103 |issue=47 |pages=17979–84 |date=November 2006 |pmid=17101991 |pmc=1693858 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0605865103 |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/103/47/17979}}</ref> Licking will also tend to [[debride]] the wound and remove gross contamination from the affected area. In a recent study, scientists have confirmed through several experiments that the protein responsible for healing properties in human saliva is, in fact, histatin. Scientists are now looking for ways to make use of this information in ways that can lead to chronic wounds, burns, and injuries being healed by saliva, making this type of treatment as common as antibiotic creams and rubbing alcohol.<ref>Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology. "Licking Your Wounds: Scientists Isolate Compound In Human Saliva That Speeds Wound Healing." ScienceDaily. ScienceDaily, 24 July 2008. </ref>
==In animals== [[File:Cat with Elizabethan collar.jpg|left|thumb|A cat with an [[Elizabethan collar]]]] [[File:Canine lick granuloma.jpg|right|thumb|[[Lick granuloma]] from excessive licking]]
It has been long observed that the licking of their wounds by dogs might be beneficial. Indeed, a dog's saliva is [[bactericidal]] against the bacteria ''[[Escherichia coli]]'' and ''[[Streptococcus|Streptococcus canis]]'', although not against coagulase positive ''[[Staphylococcus]]'' or ''[[Pseudomonas aeruginosa]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Hart BL, Powell KL |title=Antibacterial properties of saliva: role in maternal periparturient grooming and in licking wounds |journal=Physiol. Behav. |volume=48 |issue=3 |pages=383–6 |date=September 1990 |pmid=2125128 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6T0P-47XN291-4J&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=2cb90adfedae1e2e54b74d92cab4a2ed |doi=10.1016/0031-9384(90)90332-X}}</ref> Wound licking is also important in other animals. Removal of the salivary glands of mice<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bodner L, Knyszynski A, Adler-Kunin S, Danon D |title=The effect of selective desalivation on wound healing in mice |journal=Exp. Gerontol. |volume=26 |issue=4 |pages=357–63 |year=1991 |pmid=1936194 |doi=10.1016/0531-5565(91)90047-P }}</ref> and rats slows wound healing, and communal licking of wounds among rodents accelerates wound healing.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Hutson JM, Niall M, Evans D, Fowler R |title=Effect of salivary glands on wound contraction in mice |journal=Nature |volume=279 |issue=5716 |pages=793–5 |date=June 1979 |pmid=450129 |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v279/n5716/abs/279793a0.html |doi=10.1038/279793a0}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Bodner L |title=Effect of parotid submandibular and sublingual saliva on wound healing in rats |journal=Comp Biochem Physiol a Comp Physiol |volume=100 |issue=4 |pages=887–90 |year=1991 |pmid=1685381 |doi=10.1016/0300-9629(91)90309-Z }}</ref> Communal licking is common in several primate species. In [[macaques]], hair surrounding a wound and any dirt is removed, and the wound is licked, healing without infection.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dittus WP, Ratnayeke SM |title=Individual and social behavioral responses to injury in wild toque macaques (''Macaca Sinica'') |journal=International Journal of Primatology |volume=10 |issue=3 |pages=215–34 |year=1989 |url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/b61609g7563023p5/ |doi=10.1007/BF02735201}}</ref>
===Risks=== Wound licking is beneficial but too much licking can be harmful. An [[Elizabethan collar]] may be used on pet animals to prevent them from biting an injury or excessively licking it, which can cause a [[lick granuloma]]. These lesions are often infected by pathogenic bacteria such as ''Staphylococcus intermedius''.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Shumaker AK, Angus JC, Coyner KS, Loeffler DG, Rankin SC, Lewis TP |title=Microbiological and histopathological features of canine acral lick dermatitis |journal=Vet. Dermatol. |volume=19 |issue=5 |pages=288–98 |date=October 2008 |pmid=18699812 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-3164.2008.00693.x |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/bsc/vderm/2008/00000019/00000005/art00007}}</ref> Infection is another risk. Horses that lick wounds may become infected by a stomach [[parasite]], ''[[Habronema]]'', a type of [[nematode]] worm. The [[rabies]] virus may be transmitted between animals, such as the [[Greater Kudu|kudu antelopes]] by wound licking of wounds with residual infectious saliva.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Mansfield K, McElhinney L, Hübschle O, etal |title=A molecular epidemiological study of rabies epizootics in kudu (''Tragelaphus strepsiceros'') in Namibia |journal=BMC Vet. Res. |volume=2|pages=2 |year=2006 |pmid=16412222 |pmc=1382222 |doi=10.1186/1746-6148-2-2 |url=http://www.biomedcentral.com/1746-6148/2/2}}</ref>
==In humans==
===Legend=== There are many legends involving healing wounds by licking them or applying saliva. Saint [[Magdalena de Pazzi]] is said to have cured a nun of [[Skin lesion|sores]] and scabs in 1589 by licking her limbs.<ref>{{cite book | last = Fabrini | first = Placido | authorlink = |author2=Isoleri, Antonio | title = The life of St. Mary Magdalen De-Pazzi : Florentine noble, sacred Carmelite virgin| publisher = | year = 1900 | location = Philadelphia | pages = | url = https://archive.org/details/thelifeofstmarym00fabruoft | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref> The [[Roman Emperor]] [[Vespasian]] is said to have performed a healing of a blind man using his saliva.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Eve E |title=Spit in Your Eye: The Blind Man of Bethsaida and the Blind Man of Alexandria |journal=New Testament Studies |volume=54 |pages=1–17 |year=2008 |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=1683000 |doi=10.1017/S0028688508000015}}</ref> [[Pliny the Elder]] in his [[Natural History (Pliny)|Natural History]] reported that a fasting woman's saliva is an effective cure for bloodshot eyes.
===Risks===
There are potential health hazards in wound licking due to infection risk, especially in [[immunodeficiency|immunocompromised]] patients. Human saliva contains a wide variety of bacteria that are harmless in the mouth, but that may cause significant infection if introduced into a wound. A notable case was a [[diabetes|diabetic]] man who licked his bleeding [[thumb]] following a minor [[bicycle accident]], and subsequently had to have the thumb amputated after it became infected with ''[[Eikenella corrodens]]'' from his saliva.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Weil HP, Fischer-Brügge U, Koch P |title=Potential hazard of wound licking |journal=N. Engl. J. Med. |volume=346 |issue=17 |pages=1336 |date=April 2002 |pmid=11973376 |doi=10.1056/NEJM200204253461721 |url=https://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/346/17/1329.pdf?ck=nck}}</ref> The practice of [[metzitzah]] during circumcision is [[Brit milah#Medical controversy|controversial]] as it can transmit the [[Herpes simplex virus|herpes virus]] to the infant.<ref>Jennifer Warner: [http://www.webmd.com/genital-herpes/guide/20061101/rare-circumcision-ritual-carries-herpes Rare Circumcision Ritual Carries Herpes Risk] WebMD Health News, 2 August 2004</ref>
==Licking of people's wounds by animals==
===History and Legend===
{{Further|Dogs in religion}}
Dog saliva has been said by many cultures to have curative powers in people.<ref>{{cite book | last = Hatfield | first = Gabrielle | title = Encyclopedia of Folk Medicine: Old World and New World Traditions| publisher = ABC-CLIO | year = 2004 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=2GGz6708nqgC | doi = | id = | isbn = 9781576078747 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Daniels | first = Cora Linn | authorlink = |author2=C. M. Stevans | title = Encyclopfdia of Superstitions, Folklore, and the Occult Sciences of the World (Volume II)| publisher = Minerva Group Inc. | year = 2003 | pages = 668 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=Aft4c9GauRsC | isbn = 9781410209153 }}</ref> "''Langue de chien, langue de médecin''" is a French [[saying]] meaning "''A dog's tongue is a doctor's tongue''", and a Latin quote that ''"Lingua canis dum lingit vulnus curat"'' or ''"A dog's saliva can heal your wound"'' appears in a thirteenth-century manuscript.<ref>[http://www.abdn.ac.uk/bestiary/translat/19v.hti The Aberdeen Bestiary], a thirteenth-century English illuminated manuscript</ref> In [[Ancient Greece]], dogs at the [[Asclepieion|shrine]] of [[Aesculapius]] were trained to lick patients, and snake saliva was also applied to wounds.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Angeletti LR, Agrimi U, Curia C, French D, Mariani-Costantini R |title=Healing rituals and sacred serpents |journal=Lancet |volume=340 |issue=8813 |pages=223–5 |date=July 1992 |pmid=1353146 |doi=10.1016/0140-6736(92)90480-Q }}</ref> [[Saint Roch]] in the [[Middle Ages]] was said to have been cured of a plague of sores by licking from his dog.<ref>{{cite book | last = Serpell | first = James | title = In the Company of Animals: A Study of Human-animal Relationships | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 1996 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=v9gKhfo0MDgC | isbn = 9780521577793 }}</ref> The [[Assyria]]n Queen [[Semiramis]] is supposed to have attempted to resurrect the slain [[Armenia]]n king [[Ara the Beautiful]] by having the [[Caucasian Shepherd Dog|dog]] god Aralez lick his wounds.<ref>{{cite book | last = Ananikian | first = Mardiros | title = Armenian Mythology in The Mythology of All Races Volume VII | publisher = Archaeological Institute of America, Marshall Jones Co. | year = 1925 | location = New York | url =http://rbedrosian.com/ananik5c.htm }}</ref> In the [[Scottish Highlands]] in the nineteenth century, dog lick was believed to be effective for treating wounds and sores.<ref>{{cite book | last = Gregor| first = Walter| title = Notes on the Folk-Lore of the North-East of Scotland | publisher = Forgotten Books | year = 1881 | location = | pages = 251 | url = http://www.forgottenbooks.org/info/Notes_on_the_FolkLore_of_the_NorthEast_of_Scotland | isbn = 978-1-60506-178-8 }}</ref> In the [[Gospel of Luke]] (16:19-31), [[Lazarus and Dives|Lazarus the Beggar]]'s sores are licked by dogs, although no curative effects are reported by the Evangelist.
===Modern cases=== There are contemporary reports of the healing properties of dog saliva. [[Fiji]]an fishermen are reported to allow dogs to lick their wounds to promote healing,<ref name=lancet/> and a case of dog saliva promoting wound healing was reported in the ''[[The Lancet|Lancet]]'' [[medical journal]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Verrier L |title=Dog licks man |journal=Lancet |volume=1 |issue=7647 |pages=615 |date=March 1970 |pmid=4190562 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(70)91650-8 }}</ref>
===Risks=== As with the licking of wounds by people, wound licking by animals carries a risk of infection. Allowing pet cats to lick open wounds can cause [[cellulitis]]<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=DiNubile MJ, Lipsky BA |title=Complicated infections of skin and skin structures: when the infection is more than skin deep |journal=J. Antimicrob. Chemother. |volume=53 Suppl 2 |issue= |pages=ii37–50 |date=June 2004 |pmid=15150182 |doi=10.1093/jac/dkh202 |url=http://jac.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/53/suppl_2/ii37.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Yu GV, Boike AM, Hladik JR |title=An unusual case of diabetic cellulitis due to Pasturella multocida |journal=J Foot Ankle Surg |volume=34 |issue=1 |pages=91–5 |year=1995 |pmid=7780401 |doi=10.1016/S1067-2516(09)80109-9 }}</ref> and [[septicemia]]<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Hazouard E, Ferrandière M, Lanotte P, Le Marcis L, Cattier B, Giniès G |title=[Septic shock caused by Pasteurella multocida in alcoholic patients. Probable contamination of leg ulcers by the saliva of the domestic cats] |language=French |journal=Presse Med |volume=29 |issue=16 |pages=1455–7 |date=September 2000 |pmid=11039085 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Valtonen M, Lauhio A, Carlson P, etal |title=Capnocytophaga canimorsus septicemia: fifth report of a cat-associated infection and five other cases |journal=Eur. J. Clin. Microbiol. Infect. Dis. |volume=14 |issue=6 |pages=520–3 |date=June 1995 |pmid=7588825 |doi=10.1007/BF02113430 }}</ref> due to bacterial infections. Licking of open wounds by dogs could transmit [[rabies]] if the dog is infected with rabies,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Phanuphak P, Ubolyam S, Sirivichayakul S |title=Should travellers in rabies endemic areas receive pre-exposure rabies immunization? |journal=Ann Med Interne |location=Paris |volume=145 |issue=6 |pages=409–11 |year=1994 |pmid=7864502 }}</ref> although this is said by the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] to be rare.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Investigation of rabies infections in organ donor and transplant recipients—Alabama, Arkansas, Oklahoma, and Texas, 2004 |journal=MMWR Morb. Mortal. Wkly. Rep. |volume=53 |issue=26 |pages=586–9 |date=July 2004 |pmid=15241303|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm53d701a1.htm |author1=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)}}</ref> Dog saliva has been reported to complicate the healing of [[Ulcer (dermatology)|ulcers]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Knowles J |title=Dog saliva complicates the healing of ulcers |journal=Nurs Times |volume=96 |issue=4 Suppl |pages=8 |date=January 27 – February 2, 2000 |pmid=10827733 }}</ref> Another issue is the possibility of an [[allergy]] to [[protein]]s in the saliva of pets, such as [[Fel d 1]] in [[Allergy to cats|cat allergy]] and Can f 1 in [[Allergy to dogs|dog allergy]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Konieczny A, Morgenstern JP, Bizinkauskas CB, etal |title=The major dog allergens, Can f 1 and Can f 2, are salivary lipocalin proteins: cloning and immunological characterization of the recombinant forms |journal=Immunology |volume=92 |issue=4 |pages=577–86 |date=December 1997 |pmid=9497502 |pmc=1364166 |doi=10.1046/j.1365-2567.1997.00386.x }}</ref> Cases of serious infection following the licking of wounds by pets include:
*'''Dog''' **A diabetic man who was infected by ''[[Pasteurella]] dagmatis'' due to the licking of his injured toe by his dog, causing a spinal infection.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dupuy O, Garrabé E, Bordier L, Boyer B, Goasguen O, Mayaudon H, Bauduceau B |title=''Pasteurella dagmatis'' spondylodiscitis in a diabetic patient |journal=Rev Med Interne |volume=27 |issue=10 |pages=803–4 |date=October 2006 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6VMG-4K6CN72-3&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=57720fb7981e1a28bc6e8e7de2244488 |language=French |pmid=16978746 |doi=10.1016/j.revmed.2006.05.018}}</ref> **A woman recovering from knee surgery suffered a persistent infection of the knee with ''Pasteurella'' after her dog licked a small wound on her toe.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Heym B, Jouve F, Lemoal M, Veil-Picard A, Lortat-Jacob A, Nicolas-Chanoine MH |title=''Pasteurella multocida'' infection of a total knee arthroplasty after a "dog lick" |journal=Knee Surg Sports Traumatol Arthrosc |volume=14 |issue=10 |pages=993–7 |date=October 2006 |url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/p624775n6176628w/ |doi=10.1007/s00167-005-0022-5 |pmid=16468067}}</ref> **A dog lick to an Australian woman's minor burn caused septicemia and necrosis due to ''[[Capnocytophaga canimorsus]]'' infection, resulting in the loss of all her toes, fingers and a leg.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Low SC, Greenwood JE |title=''Capnocytophaga canimorsus'': infection, septicaemia, recovery and reconstruction |journal=J. Med. Microbiol. |volume=57 |issue=Pt 7 |pages=901–3 |date=July 2008 |pmid=18566152 |doi=10.1099/jmm.0.47756-0 |url=http://jmm.sgmjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=18566152}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Staff writers | title = Woman loses leg, fingers, toes from dog lick | work = Herald Sun (Australia) | pages = | language = | publisher = Herald and Weekly Times | date = 25 July 2008 | url = http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,24075396-661,00.html | accessdate = 30 January 2009 }}</ref> **''C. canimorsus'' caused acute [[renal failure]] due to septicemia in a man whose open hand wound was licked by his dog.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Anderson CE, Jayawardene SA, Carmichael P |title=A lick may be as bad as a bite: irreversible acute renal failure |journal=Nephrol Dial Transplant |volume=15 |issue= 11|pages=1883–4 |year=2000 |url=http://ndt.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/15/11/1883 |doi=10.1093/ndt/15.11.1883 |pmid=11071985}}</ref> **A 68-year-old man died from septicemia and [[necrotizing fasciitis]] after a wound was licked by his dog.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Ko Chang |author2=L. K. Siu |author3=Yen-Hsu Chen |author4=Po-Liang Lu |author5=Tun-Chieh Chen |author6=Hsiao-Chen Hsieh |author7=Chun-Lu Lin |title=Fatal ''Pasteurella multocida'' septicemia and necrotizing fasciitis related with wound licked by a domestic dog |journal=Scandinavian Journal of Infectious Diseases |volume=39 |issue=2 |pages=167–70 |year=2007 |url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~content=a770190889~db=all |doi=10.1080/00365540600786572 |pmid=17366037}}</ref> **A patient with a [[perforated eardrum]] developed meningitis after his dog passed on a ''Pasteurella multocida'' infection by licking his ear.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Godey B, Morandi X, Bourdinière J, Heurtin C |title=Beware of dogs licking ears |journal=Lancet |volume=354 |issue=9186 |pages=1267–8 |year=1999 |url=http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(99)04197-5/fulltext |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(99)04197-5 |pmid=10520644}}</ref> *'''Cat''' **A woman recovering from surgery for endometrial cancer suffered from [[Pasteurellosis|''Pasteurella multocida'' infection]] causing an [[abscess]] after her cat licked the incision.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Chun ML, Buekers TE, Sood AK, Sorosky JI |title=Postoperative wound infection with ''Pasteurella multocida'' from a pet cat |journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol |volume=188 |issue=4 |pages=1115–6 |date=April 2003 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6W9P-48PV1T3-1S&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=724e2172c0543b4bcba452a22b9f16af |doi=10.1067/mob.2003.266 |pmid=12712125}}</ref> **A [[blood donor]] whose cat licked her chapped fingers passed on ''Pasteurella'' infection to a 74-year-old [[Blood transfusion|transfusion]] recipient.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bryant BJ, Conry-Cantilena C, Ahlgren A, Felice A, Stroncek DF, Gibble J, Leitman SF |title=Pasteurella multocida bacteremia in asymptomatic plateletpheresis donors: a tale of two cats |journal=Transfusion |volume=47 |issue=11 |pages=1984–9 |date=November 2007 |url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/118485274/abstract |doi=10.1111/j.1537-2995.2007.01421.x |pmid=17958526}}</ref> **A seven-week-old boy contracted [[meningitis]] due to ''Pasteurella'' from contact with pet saliva.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Wade T, Booy R, Teare EL, Kroll S |title=''Pasteurella multocida'' meningitis in infancy – (a lick may be as bad as a bite) |journal=Eur J Pediatr |volume=158 |issue=11 |pages=875–8 |date=November 1999 |url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/6jxngneqe41f0jxk/ |doi=10.1007/s004310051232 |pmid=10541939}}</ref>
==Idiomatic use== {{wiktionary|lick one's wounds}} To "lick your wounds" means to "withdraw temporarily while recovering from a defeat"<ref>[[wiktionary:To lick one's wounds]]</ref>
The phrase was spoken by [[Marcus Antonius|Antony]] in [[John Dryden]]'s seventeenth century play ''[[All for Love (play)|All for Love]]'':<ref>{{cite book|last=Dryden|first=John|title=All for Love, or the World Well Lost|year=1677|url=http://johndryden.classicauthors.net/AllForLove/AllForLove7.html}}</ref> {{quote|They look on us at distance, and, like curs<br>Scaped from the lion's paws, they bay far off<br>And lick their wounds, and faintly threaten war.}}
==See also== * [[Cat scratch fever]] * [[Folklore]] * [[Maggot therapy]] * [[Personal grooming]] * [[Skin repair]] * [[Vampire bat#Feeding|Vampire bat feeding]] * [[Zoonosis]]

Root-Bernstein, Michele M. Root-Bernstein (1998). [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0395924928 Honey, Mud, Maggots, and Other Medical Marvels], Chapter 9. Mariner Books. {{ISBN|0-395-92492-8}}, {{ISBN|978-0-395-92492-1}} * Video clip of woman having a wound licked by a dog. [http://animal.discovery.com/beyond/player.html?playerId=203719213&categoryId=1856963514&lineupId=1847307862&titleId=2275873001 Living With The Wolfman: Licking Wounds] [[Animal Planet]], Discovery Communications, LLC.

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2017}} {{Superherobox <!--Wikipedia:WikiProject Comics--> | image = [[File:Yellowjacketcomics3.jpg|200px]] | caption = Yellowjacket, on the cover to ''Yellowjacket Comics'' #3 (November 1944) | character_name = Yellowjacket | publisher = [[Charlton Comics]] [[DC Comics]] | debut = ''Yellowjacket Comics'' #1 (September 1944) | creators = | alter_ego = Vince Harley | full_name = | species = <!-- optional --> | homeworld = <!-- optional --> | alliances = <!-- optional --> | aliases = <!-- optional: actual identities the character uses, not nicknames --> | relatives = | supports=<!--optional--> | powers = Ability to control [[yellowjacket]]s. }} '''Yellowjacket''' is a fictional [[super-hero]], and the first to be published by the company that would become [[Charlton Comics]]. He first appeared in ''Yellowjacket Comics'' #1 (September 1944)
== Publication history == Yellowjacket starred in his own title, ''Yellowjacket Comics'', which was published for ten issues from 1944 to 1946. There was no artist or writer credited for the stories. These ten issues were published by "E. Levy/Frank Comunale", which later became Charlton. When the title was renamed ''Jack in the Box'', Yellowjacket appeared in the first issue, #11. He also appeared in ''TNT Comics'' #1, which was published by "Charles Publications".
Due to copyright laws at the time of his inception, Yellowjacket lapsed into the public domain on the 28th anniversary of his initial published appearance.
Yellowjacket finally makes his [[DC Comics]] debut in [[Grant Morrison]]'s [[The Multiversity]] series. He is the first superhero on Earth 4, as well as the father of the [[President of the United States]] on that Earth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/morrison-and-quitely-tackle-watchmen-and-modern-su-212146|title=Morrison and Quitely tackle Watchmen and modern superheroes in Pax Americana|date=21 November 2014|work=avclub.com}}</ref>
== Fictional character biography == Yellowjacket's secret identity is crime writer, Vince Harley. After a group of jewel robbers attempted to kill him by pouring a box of [[yellowjacket]]s on him, he found that he had gained the ability to control the insects, and used that ability to fight crime while wearing a yellow costume with a black and yellow striped cape resembling the markings of said insect.
